debateinfo.title: URANIUM MINING IN OR NEAR AUSTRALIAN WORLD HERITAGE PROPERTIES (PROHIBITION) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Allison) agreed to:

That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to prohibit the mining, extraction, treatment and transport of any uranium or uranium ore in or near any property in Australia in the World Heritage List, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Allison) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as followsâ

The purpose of this act is to spell out the terms of a prohibited activity in any part of a World Heritage Area. For the purposes of this act a prohibited activity means the mining, extraction, treatment and transport of any uranium or uranium bearing ore.
This bill is an attempt to protect, in particular, the Kakadu World Heritage Area from further uranium mining or milling, and from any transportation of uranium ore.

The strength of this act lies in its sensible and reasonable aims which are to prevent the tainting of a World Heritage Area by uranium mining and associated activities. Having a uranium mine in a World Heritage Area is like having a large industrial grease trap in the concert hall of the Sydney Opera House. A rubbish dump in a church. A chemical factory in the Healesville sanctuary.
This bill is specifically about protecting superb world heritage areas, and in particular Kakadu World Heritage area, from the risks associated with uranium mining.

Kakadu is a magnificent National Park and World Heritage Area in the Northern Territory. It is one of only 17 World Heritage sites out of 440 globally which were inscribed for both outstanding natural and cultural heritage values according to the strict international criteria.
Kakadu was inscribed on the World Heritage register in 3 stages, 1981, 1987 and stage 3 in 1992 which included the controversial Coronation Hill area.

It contains magnificent wetlands, representatives of most of Australia's bird species. It protects almost the entire South Alligator River Catchment area, and is an area of great and abundant diversity.

From a cultural perspective I have viewed extensive rock art galleries there with art possibly dating back 40,000 years. It is a place where Aboriginal people live and interact with their environment and their heritage. Many Aboriginal people have told the Democrats over the years that it is a place they believe is too precious to be disrupted for a uranium mine.

The Government will argue that the local Aboriginal people will receive great benefits from the mine. Those benefits are supposed to flow from a minority percentage of the royalty equivalents. But in effect these payments are used to make up for the neglect by Territory and Commonwealth governments.

They are used as a justification for not giving funding from other sources for what could be best described as citizenship rights; for example basic health services, housing and basic infrastructure. The Northern Territory government and the Commonwealth governments have demonstrably and continually abrogated their responsibility for the traditional owners of Kakadu.

It is morally bankrupt for any Government in this nation, State, territory or Federal, to pressure Aboriginal people to agree to a uranium mine on their land so they can have some hope of getting basic services.

Yvonne Margarula, the Senior Traditional Owner of the Jabiluka area has done everything she can to protect her land. She has talked about her country to people all over the nation, she has quietly resisted the work started on the land, and she will not give up.
She is rightly concerned about the environmental and social impacts of the mine.

But the Government won't listen. They have tried to pretend there won't be any problems. They commissioned a social impact study that demonstrated the mine will not help the people of the area. They are working hand in hand with the company to force this mine through.
The Northern Territory government is also culpable. They have arrested Yvonne Margarula for walking on her own land. How can that be? How can the Senior Owner of land be arrested for walking on it?
How can this government spread the rot about native title that they do. These people have had native title for many years and they can't even stop a uranium mine on their land.
There are so many concerns about this mine.

One of the many concerns about uranium mining is the potential effect of radioactive spills of contaminated water and its mobilisation into the environment, particularly downstream in catchment areas.

The Government will also try to say there are no safety or environmental problems with mining uranium, they will say it is OK to take a chance on more mines in Kakadu. But remember this is a World Heritage area and you don't use Ming vases in a juggling act.
The 1985/86 Annual Report of the Office of the Supervising Scientist states:
"Disposal of uranium mill tailings in surface dams, no matter how well stabilised and protected, almost certainly involves the acceptance of eventual tailings release into the environment.

While this risk may be reduced. . . it is unlikely that any containment structure could remain totally impregnable to the natural processes of slow erosion over periods comparable to several half lives of the longest lived isotopes retained in the tailings"

Ranger and Narbarlek and the Jabiluka and Koongara deposits are in high rainfall catchment areas. Tailings from uranium extraction contain more than 70 per cent of the radioactivity of the original ore. Impacts from uranium mining and milling are measured in a geological time scale as half lives of radio nucleides and in many cases are measured in tens of thousands of years.

Unauthorised and authorised releases or spills have occurred at both Ranger and Narbarlek in the past. A notable spill at Narbarlek occurred as a result of a split in a pipeline allowing about 5kgs of tailings slurry to spray outside the Narbarlek restricted release zone.

In early 1995 during a heavy wet season, the management of Ranger applied to release contaminated water from Retention Pond 2 in the restricted release zone, which would have flowed into the Magela Creek system.

The Traditional owners of an area of Arnhem Land downstream from the mine in the Magela Creek region objected strongly to the release and sought an injunction to prevent the release from the Northern Territory Supreme Court which was heard on the 16th March.

The Judge rejected the application for a permanent injunction and effectively paved the way for the release of contaminated water saying `someone' had to explain to the traditional owners and affected peoples downstream that the releases were safe, because the scientists said so.

The traditional owners point out that if this contaminated radioactive water was to be put in the Sydney water and food supply there would be outrage, yet they were expected to support such a release. Fortunately the time involved in the court proceedings meant that the flow of the creek had slowed to the point that the Office of the Supervising Scientist advised against the release.

It is still possible that the Ranger management (or even the managers of other mines should they be approved by the Coalition Government), will request to release contaminated water in the future as it has stated it has only deferred the release.

This controversy followed earlier requests for release of contaminated water in 1986/87, and 1989. The 1989 incident Ranger released water by allowing it to overflow to a spillway into Djalk mara Billabong using the rationale that the Billabong would act as a filter for the water.
Despite the Office of the Supervising Scientist refusing to give approval, the Northern Territory Government did, and the release went ahead.
Following this incident, the Office of the Supervising Scientist released this statement in their 1988/89 report:

"Over the past year or so, Ranger/ERA has shown an increasing tendency to regard certain environmental requirements as `legal technicalities' the strict application of which ERA has described as an impediment to developing the Best Practicable Technology'. Ranger has been reluctant to adhere strictly to the ER's where compliance leads to operational inconvenience, or additional expenditure and it has disregarded technical advice from the OSS resulting in a number of incidents or deliberate actions whose environmental implications are undesirable".

For all these reasons, spills and the potential for more, the effect on the Aboriginal comminutes and the effect on one of the most precious places on earth, I ask all honourable Senators in this place to forget their party and industry allegiance just for one minute.

We've inherited unique, rich world, with clean rivers and seas, an abundance of life in all of its different forms and rich soils and resources. We have a chance, possibly unique, to protect this and to live in a way that protects it for future generations, to live simply so that others may simply live.

Think of the world you want to pass on to your children and grandchildren, the life chances you want them to have, the places you would like them to see, the experiences you would like them to enjoy. With all that in mind, let's be very clear, nuclear accidents sully and contaminate our environment and our very genetic blueprints on a time line measured in generations.

I am sure when you take the chance to honestly reflect on my words and on the content of this bill, you will all agree that Kakadu is too precious to put at risk, too precious to expose to further radioactive waste.

Now with the possibility of more uranium mining rearing its ugly head again in the Kakadu World Heritage Area, the Democrats are re-introducing a bill as we believe it is vitally important this mine does not go ahead.
As it now stands, the Australian people have an invaluable treasure-an area of unique scenic, archaeological and ecological importance.
In a report on archaeological research in Kakadu National Park, leading Australian archaeologist, Dr Rhys Jones, and Tia Negerevich wrote:

"Along the base of the great cliffs . . . are rock shelters which constitute one of the world's most important storehouses of information about the prehistory and the art of hunting and gathering man. In terms of the number and age of occupied rock shelters, and the staggering profusion and antiquity of the brilliant rock art sites, the Kakadu area can be compared with some of the classic archaeological locations of the world.

. . . in Kakadu, the Aboriginal owners are the direct descendants of the people who lived in the rock shelters and who painted the art . . . The conjunction of living Aboriginal traditions, and extremely diverse and rich landscape and the wealth of archaeological sites, some with proven antiquity back to 23,000 years ago, makes the Kakadu a key zone for research into the prehistory of Australia." (Rhys Jones and Negerevich)

The writers liken the importance of the Kakadu sites to the Dordogne cave paintings in France, with the added factor of the direct descent of the traditional owners from the inhabitants of the area over 23,000 years ago.

There would be a significant increase of dust in the atmosphere, and that, as well as other adverse ecological effects of such a mine would cause direct degradation of the archaeological sites, as well as the indirect degradation caused by scars on the landscape from roads to the mining area, noise and air pollution, and pollution of the water table. None of this must be allowed to occur. The area is of such obvious international significance that its inclusion in the World Heritage listing for Kakadu is utterly appropriate.

It is no good to say, we only produce uranium ore, or we only produce it for power, or our uranium can't go into weapons. The fact of the matter is, we are producing a material which will become waste which has to be dealt with and will last many thousands of years. The fact of the matter also is that there are no guarantees, no absolute guarantees that Australian Uranium is not being enriched, flag swapped and used in weapons manufacture.

We must be responsible with the uranium in this country, we must admit that it is producing waste and the effects of that waste in biological and environmental damage are measured in a geological time scale, not a human time scale.

The management and final disposal of radioactive waste has presented some of the most profound and enduring difficulties for nuclear power and uranium mining. This is in start contrast to the great improvements in managing and disposing of almost all other types of wastes created by modern societies.

Wastes from nuclear reactors have some of the very longest lived wastes and so need to be kept isolated from the biosphere for hundreds of thousands of years. It is virtually impossible to guarantee there will never be leaks, cracks, earthquakes, breakdown in maintenance or other occurrences which could cause leakage of the waste material in the time scale needed. Both ocean and land style disposal are being used globally for attempted disposal and there are many, many problems.

I would also anticipate an argument from the Government that our uranium is needed to fill a gap in the increasing demand for uranium for the power industry. However our information is that the industry is actually contracting.

Between 1994-2000 approximately 60 reactors globally will be past their design lifespan. There are 48 new reactors in the pipeline which are supposedly coming on stream between 1994-2000. Of the 48 planned perhaps as many as one third have financial or political problems and may not ever be completed. However there are also existing reactors being decommissioned which will be past their design lifespan. For example 10 plants in the US, 20 in the UK, 5 in Japan and 3 in Germany will be past their design lifespans Even assuming all 48 overcome financial and political problems there will still be 12 fewer by the year 2000 than there are now. Therefore reactor numbers and subsequently nuclear power is actually decreasing.

The current demand for uranium is about 60,000 tonnes per year globally taking into account the fact that new reactors initially use more because a full core load is needed. Supply at present is about 30,000 tonnes per year because a number of mines in Canada, the US, Australia and Kazakhstan operate at 50 per cent or less capacity. This is offset by large stockpiles and large quantities of enriched (in some cases up to 95 per cent) uranium on the marked from the USSR (between 500 and 700 tonnes) and the USA (600 tonnes).

Finally, we must remember that our uranium doesn't get special treatment in the case of theft or use for terrorism. This century has seen the proliferation of several terrorist friendly technologies--plastic explosives are one example. However some of the most potentially dangerous technologies are those associated with nuclear, biological and chemical means of warfare. Of these the worst scenarios are where terrorists achieve control over nuclear facilities, material or even weapons.

The disaster at Chernobyl was an accident; the deliberate destruction of an operating reactor's containment could have equally catastrophic consequences. These are problems recognised by many Governments in the world.

To sum up, there are simply no good arguments for Australia to sell its uranium overseas. To use the fatuous notion that if we don't sell it, some other country will and we won't get the money is like saying we should sell cocaine, or the Cartels in Colombia will sell it and we won't get the money. There are problems with the entire nuclear cycle, from producing and transporting the ore, to enrichment, to use, to waste and to disposal or use of that waste. And those problems are measured in our very genetic blueprints and in a timescale most of us can't imagine.
The Australian Democrats implore the Senate to deal responsibly with this vitally important legislation and ensure its speedy passage through both houses.
Debate (on motion by Senator Calvert) adjourned.

The speeches read as followsâ
The main purpose of this bill is to insert into the Excise Tariff Act 1921 Excise Tariff Proposals Nos. 1 and 2 of 1998.
As part of its aviation policy, the Government reduced the rate of excise and customs duty on aviation gasoline ("avgas") to $0.17403 per litre, with effect from 3 July 1997.

On 31 January 1998, the legislation package implementing the fuel substitution reforms, which I will discuss in greater detail shortly, came into effect. Part of these reforms involved a complete restructure of item 11 of the Schedule to the Excise Tariff Act 1921. As a result of that restructure the duty rate for avgas was set at $0.18003 per litre. This rate did not reflect the Government's 1997 decision in relation to avgas.
The amendments made in this bill reduce the excise duty payable on avgas, as from 3 July 1997, to $0.17403 per litre.

On 31 January 1998, a package of 9 acts, implementing the Government's Budget decision to combat revenue loss through the minimisation of fuel substitution practices commenced. The prime object was to ensure that petroleum products dutiable at concessional rates of excise duty were not used as fuels in internal combustion engines.

Fuel substitution avoids paying the correct excise. It also is a fraud on consumers and on the vast majority of those involved in the petroleum products distribution and retail system who follow the rules.

Moreover, in many cases, use of petroleum products not designed for use in engines can greatly harm engine performance and expose consumers to great danger as the blends contained in these products may have a much lower flashpoint than proper diesel.
These acts were passed by the Parliament in the 1997 Spring sittings.

The petroleum industry was consulted at all stages of policy development and implementation of this package. It was concerned the new structure may create misunderstandings as to how much excise was payable on some petroleum products intended for particular uses, particularly products used otherwise than as fuels.

Accordingly, the technical amendments contained in this bill are designed to remove any such uncertainty. The amendments insert new subheadings of "other" in all subitems of item 11 except subitem 11(A) and 11(D), to cover petroleum products used for purposes other than as fuel.
These amendments do not widen the intended scope of the fuel substitution minimisation legislation.
Other technical amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 are discussed in the bill's explanatory memorandum.

This bill provides for the imposition of annual charges to recover costs incurred by the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism (DIST) in monitoring telecommunications industry development plans prepared by carriers under the Telecommunications Act 1997.

Part 3 of the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Charges) Act 1997 provides for the imposition of an annual charge on a carrier licence that is in force at the beginning of a financial year beginning on or after 1 July 1998. The amount of the annual charge is ascertained in accordance with a disallowable instrument determined by the Australian Communications Authority (ACA). The act provides for a limit on the total amount of this charge on carriers having regard to the amounts attributable to the ACA's and ACCC's telecommunications functions and powers for the immediately preceding financial year, the proportion of the Commonwealth's contribution to the budget of the International Telecommunication Union for the calendar year that is to be recovered from carriers and an estimate of the grants likely to be made by the Minister during the financial year to fund consumer representation and research in relation to telecommunications.

Currently, the licence charge payable by telecommunications carriers does not recover costs incurred by DIST. The bill provides that, in addition to the amounts mentioned above, the total charges imposed on carrier licences in force at the beginning of a financial year may include an amount determined, by a written instrument made by the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, to be the proportion of DIST's costs for the immediately preceding financial year that is attributable to the administration of the industry development plan requirements contained in Part 2 of Schedule 1 to the Telecommunications Act 1997.

The cost associated with the administration of Part 2 of Schedule 1 to the Telecommunications Act 1997 is expected to be in the order of $600,000 in the first year and is likely to grow as the number of carriers increases. The bill will enable these costs to be recovered by the Commonwealth.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chris Evans) adjourned.
Ordered that these bills be listed on the Notice Paper as separate orders of the day.

debateinfo.title: CAPTIONING FOR THE DEAF AND HEARING IMPAIRED BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Stott Despoja)âby leaveâagreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to require captioning of certain television programs and videos for the deaf and hearing impaired, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Stott Despoja) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: âI table the explanatory memorandum and move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as followsâ

The Captioning for the Deaf and Hearing Impaired Bill 1998 aims to increase the availability of captioned services for the benefit of the deaf and hearing impaired Australians. This will be done in three ways:
(i) by increasing the broadcasting of captioned television and like services;
(ii) by captioning of videos for hire and sale; and
(iii) by having television sets and videos with the ability to decode captioning signals.

The proposed amendments require changes to the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 to require the captioning of each television program on or after 1 July 2000, for those programs which start on or after 4pm and before 10:30pm, as well as each news and current affairs television program on or after 1 July 2000 and every program on or after 1 July 2010.

Changes to the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 will require videos for hire or sale on or after 1 July 2002 to include captions, and hired or sold televisions will have to be able to decode captioning signals on or after 1 July 2002. Failure to meet these requirements will be the basis for a claim of discrimination.

At present only 15 per cent of all Australian broadcasts carry closed captions. This is comparatively low compared with that of the United Kingdom and the United States broadcasts, which are at a rate of 45 per cent and 90 per cent respectively. We are behind and for the benefit of deaf and hearing impaired Australians we need to catch up. The United Kingdom Broadcasting Act requires 50 per cent of all commercial broadcasts must be captioned by 1998 and in the United States the Telecommunications Act requires everything must be captioned by 2008. The proposal set out in this bill are consistent with international practice and provide a compromise between complete captioning now and moves towards complete captioning.

Under existing laws there is a commitment to captioning through Codes of Practice. Section 123 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 requires commercial broadcasters to develop and abide by codes of practice relating to captioning. The ABC's Code of Practice makes similar provision. However, the level of broadcasting in Australia with captioning is relatively low by international standards, despite these legislative options.

I however acknowledge the significant contribution of Australian broadcasters in increasing the level of captioning. For example, I understand SBS captions nearly 45 per cent of their programs, excluding the re-broadcast foreign news programs.

Without legislation setting particular targets it is very likely those in our community will be forced to rely on the existing provisions of the Disability Discrimination Act 1992. Section 24 of that act makes it unlawful for any person who provides goods and services (whether for payment or not) to discriminate against another person on the grounds of another person's disability. The term "services" would arguably include television and possibly videos.

The case of Scott & Another v Telstra Corporation Ltd (1995) EOC 92-717 related to a complaint made against Telstra for not providing a service to a profoundly deaf person. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner found for the plaintiff for the following reasons:
(i) the definition of a `service' proposed by Telstra was denoted as a product, and not as the purpose of the product for which it was to be supplied;
(ii) by providing a service that those members of the community who were not profoundly deaf could access, therefore indirectly discriminating against those who were; and

(iii) the magnitude of unjustifiable hardship faced by the plaintiff was weighed between the difficulty facing the respondent in supplying the service, as opposed to the benefit received from the provision of the service. The decision was made on the basis that the financial impact did not outweigh the benefits that the service could provide to people with profoundly limited hearing.
This decision indicates the very real possibility that failure to provide captioning is open to a finding of discrimination.

Challenging captioning on the basis of discrimination legislation would be an expensive and lengthy undertaking, with no guarantee of a positive outcome for any parties. Therefore, clear legislation is an appropriate measure to ensure captioning targets meet the needs of this particular sector of Australians. As a further indication of the need for legislative intervention, the Federal, New South Wales and Western Australian governments have policies in place which require compulsory captioning for all their advertisements and videos.
This bill provides a clear statement of what measures need to be undertaken and will avoid the need for litigation and hardship in the deaf and hearing impaired community.

Taking into account international practices and through consultation with the National Working Party on Captioning (NWPC), I have suggested the following captioning goals. The proposed amendment stipulates that prime time television segments (ie starting at or after 4pm and before 10:30pm) are to be captioned on or after 1 July 2000, as well as each news and current affairs television program service on or after 1 July 2000. I believe these are achievable with sufficient lag time to allow appropriate planning and implementation.
The benefits of this bill extend far beyond those for the deaf and hearing impaired.

This bill is a pedestal for the Australian Parliament to stand on in an era of rapid technological changes. We have the technology and we must grasp the possibilities for the benefits of all Australians. We have moved to accept disabled groups in our community through positive legislation, and the next step is to make sure the ongoing technology is available to these groups. This bill makes that step for the deaf and hearing impaired, so that they too can have the benefits of broadcasting and videos.
Many deaf and hearing impaired members of the community have contacted me with their views. Their perspective is an insight into the importance of this legislation. One writer stated:

"Caption television has brought many deaf and hearing impaired people into the world again. Denied radio, unable to hear in theatres or cinemas, uncomfortable at the most ordinary social gatherings, the deaf and severely hearing impaired, it is not to much to say, often they live for their bit information and entertainment on captioned television. It has become their contact with the world and more importantly, a means of keeping in contact with their family, younger people, giving them a point of contact in their otherwise quite isolated existence. Yet in Australia so little is provided for them on television. The medium which has impacted so much on every hearing person in our culture has almost passed by the deaf and hearing impaired with only a mere nod in their direction. For many of these people it is like being locked out of their culture."
Clearly, captioning will have a significant benefit to this community.

Further, this is an excellent opportunity for Australia to develop this technology, and benchmark the system for other international markets. Captioning is an international necessity and through domestic captioning we have the potential to develop an international industry with important consequences for our culture and our place in the family of nations. Our export documentaries, films and television programming has international appeal and we can value add to this through an active captioning industry in Australia.

These amendments will greatly benefit the lifestyles of those who are deaf or hearing impaired. Their ability to keep up with current affairs, or merely for entertainment, will affect the way they picture themselves as included members of society. As an inclusive and participatory community we must always make sure each cohort in the community is included. This bill ensures the deaf and hearing impaired are not excluded from the central place of broadcasting and videos in our communities.

The principal problems anticipated are the costs. The proposed amendments will shift the costs to the community and the commercial broadcasters. The costs the community will incur will become standardised, as the entire population will incur the same fee. This is important so there is no inequality. This cost is important for the community to meet, and by `normalising' this cost it also integrates the deaf and hearing impaired further into our communities. The assumption is made that commercial networks will absorb additional costs. The public broadcasting ABC and SBS may require additional funding. A compromise has been made with the limitation of mandatory captioning to only take place within the prime time television allotments and the period for introduction is lengthy as a recognition that some costs are involved. I believe these costs are reasonable and will be a significant investment for those in our community who are deaf or hearing impaired.

At present a sales tax exemption exists on television sets with the decoding ability for these disadvantaged groups. Such an exemption would be unsatisfactory with the introduction of these amendments, as everyone would incur the charges for a television with a teletext decoder. However to revoke this tax exemption would be a small sacrifice considering the consequences of these amendments. This sacrifice is supported by deaf lobby groups, as long as these amendments are introduced.

The aim of this bill will not only be to extend the captioned television broadcasts to the Australian deaf and hearing impaired community, but to also provide the opportunity to hire or purchase a newly released videos and television sets. The National Working Party on Captioning (NWPC) has identified their aim for all new video releases were to be captioned by July 1999. The proposed amendment of the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 supports these goals, and identifies July 1999 to be the date that any person to discriminate against another person who has a hearing disability by the sale or hire of a new video that does not include captions, is unlawful.

This amendment also stipulates that discrimination against another person on or after 1 July 2002 by the selling or hiring by one person to the other person who has a hearing disability, of a television set that is not able to decode teletext, is again, unlawful. Both parts to this subsection will increase the quality of life for the community of the deaf and hearing impaired. A more equitable access to the entertainment industry in both public and private settings will also be achieved with the adoption of these proposals.
This bill will not only improve the quality of life for those who are deaf or hearing impaired, it will further their integration into our community.
Debate (on motion by Senator Calvert) adjourned.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâAt the request of Senator Lees, I move:

speech.para: That the Carrier Licence Conditions (Optus Mobile Pty Ltd) Declaration 1997 (Amendment No.1 of 1997), made under the Telecommunications Act 1997 , be disallowed.
That the Carrier Licence Conditions (Optus Networks Pty Ltd) Declaration 1997 (Amendment No. 1 of 1997), made under the Telecommunications Act 1997 , be disallowed.
That the Carrier Licence Conditions (Vodaphone Pty Limited) Declaration 1997 (Amendment No. 1 of 1997), made under the Telecommunications Act 1997 , be disallowed.

The Democrats have moved these motions today because we believe that both Optus and Vodafone should have majority Australian ownership in their share equity. This is the Democrats' philosophy and, when it comes to both companies floating their equity, we argue that the conditions under which they received their licences should remain in forceâthat is, the majority Australian ownership. We think that the amendments the government has made to the carriers' licence conditions allow both of these companies to be foreign owned and that that is just plain wrong. The Democrats believe that we should ensure that these private companies operating in Australia are majority Australian owned, just as we believe that the government should maintain its ownership of Telstra so we can be sure of a continuing, high-quality, affordable telecommunications industry here in Australia.

However, it did not come as any surprise when the Treasurer approved amendments to Optus's articles of association, which had the effect of removing references to foreign ownership. This means two things: firstly, that the Treasurer removed any role for the parliament in determining the outcomes from this delegated legislation and, secondly, that Optus can now effectively become a 100 per cent foreign owned company. Whilst we are advised that the Foreign Investment Review Board will have an overriding concern with any foreign acquisition or takeover of these companies, we are only too well aware of the practical limitations of that particular branch of the Treasurer's department in maintaining Australian majority ownership. Ultimately, we believe that when companies are floated on the Stock Exchange they should clearly be required to continue to maintain majority Australian ownership. These instruments allow the watering-down of the very licence conditions that these two mobile phone operators agreed to when they commenced operation in the Australian market.

The issue of the closure of the analog mobile phone network cannot be divorced from this debate. I do not want to deal in detail with this issue but it should not go unmentioned. In 1992 the Labor Party struck a deal with Vodafone which enabled the company to provide a mobile phone network which was exclusively digital. They did not have to provide an analog service. The exchange for this was the requirement for Vodafone to have majority Australian ownership by 2003. It has been proven that digital mobile phones are often useless in rural and regional areas and people who live there simply do not get the same kind of service that we in major cities benefit from.

The Democrats have stated before that we consider the closure of the analog system to be a mistake. During the debate on the telecommunications bill in 1996 we moved amendments to retain the analog system, but the closure of the analog system is now enshrined in legislation and if it were to be repealed the Commonwealth says it would have to pay compensation to the carriers to change the policy, although Senator Alston was never willing to say what this cost would be or even engage in negotiations with the carriers.

The government has now come to the realisation that the closure of the analog system is not good telecommunications policy. The minister announced that the Australian Communications Authority would undertake a review into the analog mobile phone network in regional areas and report to the minister by 30 June this year. The minister announced a package of measures designed, he said, to ensure that all areas of Australia currently receiving analog mobile phone coverage will continue to enjoy reasonably equivalent coverage after the system is meant to close on 31 December 1999. But the most ridiculous part of the whole review is that any recommendations reached by the ACA on the extension of analog coverage would have to be agreed by the three carriers, Telstra, Optus and Vodafone. The recommendations of one of the government's own departments will potentially be overridden by the carriers, who are closing the system against customer service requirements. The provision of a reasonably equivalent analog to digital phone service for rural and regional Australia seems to be a very long way off.

Another part of this very strange situation is the promise of new satellite phones being available and being able to be used anywhere. This is simply another deception. Anyone with even the smallest knowledge of telecommunications and mobile phones can tell you that this technology is not fully developed. Even when it is the handsets will cost thousands of dollars. The system being talked about is called Iridium and those handsets cost approximately $US3,000 at present. I doubt that your average farmer would regard that as a very cost effective replacement for the analog handset even if there is a reasonable future take-up of the technology. We do not know what the costs for connection and calls are likely to be either. Australians living in rural and regional areas have had to fight hard for equal access to telecommunications. The privatisation of Telstra worries people in the bush, and quite rightly so. As we enter into the digital age and with the government so very keen to sell Telstra to the highest bidder, these people will simply be left behind unless the government makes the right decisions in this crucial policy area.

Vodafone and Optus were both required at the time they were granted their mobile telephony licence to be majority Australian owned. In Vodafone's case they had until 2003 to achieve this outcome. The Democrats believe that the decision to terminate these particular licence conditions should be disallowed. We also believe that the Treasurer's decision to amend Optus's articles of association is wrong. The government will say that we are sending out a negative signal to those companies who want to invest in Australia. The Democrats simply do not agree with that assertion. We have the very old-fashioned view that the ground rules should be clearly and concisely set out and that we should stick to them. We want to send a strong signal to foreign investors: you are welcome to Australia as long as you prove your commitment to the Australian market by having majority Australian equity and by giving something back to the community.

This issue and the closure of the analog mobile phone system should send a very clear message to governments of all persuasions on the dangers of making technical specific policy based on commercial favours. Let us hope that the government is not going to make a similar mistake with its digital television policy. I guess that the government thinks that in the three days they have set aside for public hearings into digital television we should be able to reach a conclusion about it. The Democrats urge the government to consider very carefully the long-term implications of shutting off a crucial means of telecommunications, whether phones or television. These policy decisions are not lost on the electorate, especially in rural and regional areas where these decisions take on mammoth proportions. Australian owned companies benefit Australians. We reject the government's attempt to remove foreign ownership restrictions on Vodafone and Optus and we move the motion of disallowance.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of the opposition I rise to indicate that we support these motions for disallowance. Senator Allisonâand some Independent members of the House of Representatives during the debate on this a month or so agoâtalked at some length on the issue of the analog versus the digital network. That is not an issue that we believe is relevant to this particular debate.

speech.para: These regulations are about one issue; and that is the level of foreign ownership that should be allowed for two particular carriers. The opposition has already indicated that we support the government's decision to have an inquiry to report by, I think, the end of June of this year over what way we can ensure that the digital mobile phone network can provide the same coverage as the existing analogue system to Australians, particularly in rural areas. That is a debate we will have at that time.

We in the opposition will have to be strongly convinced about leaving an analogue system in place so that you end up with two different standards for the future for a mobile phone system and what some might call a generous use of spectrum and so on, with all the problems consumers will have in the long run with two different receivers or having to manufacture a digital and analog telephone receiver all in one unit. Those are issues to be debated at that time.

Why the opposition supports the Australian Democrats' motion is that we were the ones, when we were in government, who established the rules for the licences to be given to Optus and Vodafone. We made it clear at the time that we wanted both these companies to be majority Australian owned. When the licences were granted the successful applicants for those licences, Optus and Vodafone, accepted those rules.

I know the view has been put that since 1 July we have had an open, deregulated system such that anybody who wants to be a licensed carrier can get a licence after meeting some very basic requirements and that you can be a carrier with full foreign ownership, but we believe that although that is a point to note, both these carriers, Optus and Vodafone, when they got their licence knew that on 1 July 1997 there would be an open deregulatory regime. It was made clear in the original decision of the Labor government way back in 1991-92 that in 1997 the regulatory regime would be opened up and there would be an open system for people who wanted to invest. It would be an open regime which would be more competitive but, first, we would go through a period of five years of first a duopoly and then a triopoly.

They both knew that they would be the rules that they were bidding for. They accepted those rules and made their judgment accordingly. The Labor government at the time made it clear that one of the justifi cations that we supported for allowing competition against the then Telecom monopoly was the creation and further development of an indigenous Australian telecommunications industry in all aspects. We recognised that telecommunications, communications and all the new technologies that are coming forth will be one of the growth areas of industry in Australia and in the world economy, and we wanted to make sure that we got our fair share of it, not just as a supplicant for overseas companies but by having investment in Australia by Australians, developing jobs in Australia and exporting those services and skills to Asia, where there would be the biggest growth rate of all in developing communications.

I have used the figure beforeâas have othersâthat in the first 100 years of telephones in the world about 500 million people were connected to telephones. It is suggested that in the next 10 years, from the mid-1990s, in Asia alone another half billion people would need telephone connections, an enormous growth opportunity that we ought to be part of. We want to be part of it with Australian based companies that are Australian owned. We want to make sure we get those opportunities so that is why we put those requirements on those two companies.

They have a special advantage over all the new ones which have come since 1 July. They had an opportunity to establish themselves as the second and third carriers in Australia in a triopoly arrangement which would give them significant advantages in establishing their infrastructure and establishing themselves in the marketplace before others came. That is an advantage that was not insignificant. Whether those companies have taken advantage of it is for others to judge, but that was the rule.

We in the Labor Party are not opposed to foreign investment; we have never been opposed to foreign investment. We welcome foreign investment in our telecommunications network, whether on the hardware side or the software side. This is a global industry. We make it clear that we think it is not unreasonable to have an Australian component developing in Australia, using the management and technical skills of our people to develop that industry and create jobs in Australia.

We believe it is unfortunate that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has chosen to allow these rules to be changed. I have spoken to both Optus and Vodafone. Of course they support the government's position of changing the regulations to allow up to 100 per cent overseas ownership, as I understand it, from these regulations. Vodafone has said quite openly to the opposition that when they float the company in the next two or three years in accordance with the 2002 deadline they expect there to be majority Australian ownership. We are delighted to hear that and we would encourage them to make sure that occurs.

We would also have to say that there are plenty of opportunities for these companies to get Australian shareholders. Institutional investors in Australia and the growth of the superannuation funds mean there will be no shortage of investment funds in Australia for our own indigenous superannuation funds to invest in well run, well managed telecommunications companies in Australia that are growing in a growing market. Therefore, they will have an opportunity to raise that money.

The Optus issue has been a bit more complicated, and I admit that, because of the problems Optus had in dealing with a restructuring of their own company to get themselves out of some difficulties with the cost of investment in the cable roll-out which took place over the last couple of years. We all know that cable has cost them. They have had to write off several hundreds of millions of dollars, if not a billion dollars plus, on the cost of the roll-out, and they have yet to get a return.

We know that, last year, one of the major foreign shareholders, Bell South, decided enough was enough and sold out of the company. The only other major shareholder that was willing to buy from themâthough I think there was a considerable dispute for a while over the priceâwas Cable and Wireless. Cable and Wireless indicated, I think, that Bell South would have to take some of the losses for the cable roll-out from the price they were paid and that occurred. It meant that Cable and Wireless were sitting on close to a 50 per cent shareholding. Mayne Nickless have now indicated that they would like to sell out of Optus, and Cable and Wireless might like to buy their 25 per cent share, either as a trade sale or whenever the float takes place.

One must remember that Optus has been promising for a number of years now that, always `next year', the float of the company would take place and it has never taken place. There are a number of other institutional investors in Australia who are a little cranky about the fact that they invested in Optus many years ago on the basis that there would be a float soon, so that they could get the real value of their shares. That float has not taken place because of some of the difficulties the company has had in investing in the cable rollout and the restructuring with Optus Vision, et cetera.

Nevertheless, Optus has been a very successful new entrant into the Australian market, as has Vodafone. They are already making significant profit on the business of international phone calls, long distance and mobile. They are making very significant profits, and we are very pleased they are. The competition they have provided to Telstra in that area has been excellent, and the consumer has got lower prices. This is a vindication of the Labor government's policy of allowing competition back in 1991-92. Because they are making good profits now, we believe there is every reason for Australians to invest and to want to maintain majority ownership of these two important telecommunications companies as they grow in the Australian market.

Although those companies may claim they could raise more capital overseas at a lower interest rate, or think they will have more flexibility to compete or a more competitive arrangement, if they were allowed to have full foreign ownership, or certainly increased foreign ownership to levels above 51 per cent, we do not accept that automatically. We believe that the profits they are making mean that they should not have any great difficulty at all in raising their capital in Australia and in raising the interest of Australian investors, particularly from our super funds. Why can't we ensure that Australian small investors, through their super funds, get a big as possible slice of what is a profitable industry with a turnover of already $20 billion and growing at 15 to 20 per cent per annum?

Therefore, because we established the principle that these companies should be maintained in majority Australian ownership and minority foreign ownership for the development and advantage of Australia, we believe that we should support this motion to disallow this regulation. If the government has the numbers to reject the Democrats' disallowance motion, when we come to government in a few months time after the election we will inherit the decision that this government has made. Of course, at that time, whether we like it or not, we will have to make some judgments about what we can do, but we would always encourage these two companies to be in Australian majority ownership. Therefore, the opposition supports the disallowance motion moved by the Democrats.

talk.start.para: âThis disallowance motion is discriminatory and will not achieve the objective of its mover, which is to attempt to ensure that mobile phone operators within Australia have majority Australian ownership. That will not occur if we disallow this regulation. I ask you: how will it occur? You know as well as I do that Optus and, indeed, new players that come into the field will not be bound by the foreign ownership provisions. It is a nonsense to get up here and performâthough I must admit Senator Schacht was not performing, he wasâ
âHe never does perform; that's the problem.
âHe is a conspicuous non-performer.
âNo, I did not mean that.
âAddress your remarks through the chair, Senator Harradine.

âI did not mean it the way they are taking it. I believe that we have to look at the facts. The facts are that, if we disallow this, we are not going to affect what Optus is able to do, because Optus went to the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and, with his approval, changed its articles of association, and they could do this under the licence. They are not obliged to have a majority Australian ownership, nor are any new players that come on to the field in this particular area. Let us remember that there is deregulation, and that deregulation had the approval of the opposition as well as the government.
âI explained that the two licensees got the advantage of being established, Senator Harradine.
âSenator Schacht, you have had your chance.

âI understand that, but here, if we disallow that, we are discriminating against one of the licensees and in favour of Optus. If you want to do that, you can do it. But I do not think that that is an appropriate way for legislation or regulations to apply; they should apply equally and fairly to all.

speech.para: The effect of this is really to target Optus. I say this to the Senate: I carry no brief for any of the companies which provide mobile phone coverage here. I am aware that Vodafone has said that its regional headquarters for the whole Asia-Pacific area is to be in Australia and is, in fact, in Australia. They have recruited a person from South Africa, a very active entrepreneurial person, to be their chief in Australia. He is taking out Australian citizenship and has got his family over here.

That brings me to the next point. Optus had in their articles of association that the majority of their board members should be Australian. As I understand that, that may not apply. Chris Gent, Group Chief Executive of Vodafone, has written to me. In the letter he said:

We understand however, that Optus may possibly still be subject to surviving conditions relating to the appointment of Australian citizens as directors. While we have been unable to verify this, we believe that parity in this regard is appropriate. We seek no more favourable treatment than Optus on this issue, on confirmation of the Optus situation, Vodafone would amend its articles of association to specifically provide that a majority of the directors of Vodafone Network Pty Limited, the mobile phone licensee, will be Australian citizens. We anticipate that if necessary this could be successfully completed within 2 months.

I think that shows Vodafone's bona fides in respect of its commitment to Australia. They have indicated that they would love to have Australian funds. At the present moment they are, I think, only 10 per cent Australian owned. Nonetheless, they are prepared to play their role and continue their investments in Australia and from Australia into the big Asian market when things get a little better there.

There are a number of other things that I could say. On the analog question, yes, the termination of analog in Australia was a matter of agreement between the government and the opposition. I am disappointed with that decision because of the effect on the bush. Obviously we are all awaiting the ACA report which I think comes forward on 13 June. But, even so, as far as Vodafone is concerned it has already agreed with the ACA on the retention of 159 analog leased stations. When Vodafone won the licence, analog covered only five per cent of landmass. Vodafone now has 90 per cent of population access to digital. It also owns 10 per cent of Globalstar, which is designed to cover 100 per cent of the population.

talk.start.para: âBy satellite that is; I think you mean.

âYes, by low orbital satellites. By the way, if the land is at any great height, it will enable the use of small handset units. They have to have in operation, by some time in 1999, the dual mode operation which of course goes from terrestrial towers to the satellite when users are out of range of the towers. The Dubbo tracking station is used to bring satellites into the right orbit. Experimental work is being done on this at the present moment. I mention that simply because I would hope that this ability of rural people to have accessâ
âAt reasonable cost. But that is notâ
âYes, reasonable cost. I agree with you, Senator Schacht. That is absolutely essential. But, as you say, that is not the point we are dealing with here. These are quite separate issues.

speech.para: I return to the point and appeal to Senator Allison. If we do vote for your disallowance motion it will, I believe, discriminate against one of the current operators, and that is Vodafone. I do not believe it is proper for parliament to so discriminate. I think it is a bad approach to legislative and regulative arrangements.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI will not detain the Senate long in view of Senator Harradine's comments. I simply say that he has put his finger on the nub of the issue, and that is that the effect of this disallowance motion, if it were carried, would be a fundamental discrimination against one out of two of those newer entrants. It seems to be an issue that has completely gone over Senator Schacht's head. He really just talked in general terms about foreign ownership and the ALP's obvious irresistible inclination to opportunism on that issue in the lead-up to an election. It is beyond belief that Senator Schacht could not understand that Optus will not be affected by this disallowance motion but that Vodafone would fundamentally be affected.

speech.para: I congratulate Senator Harradine for clarifying Vodafone's position in relation to regional headquarters and majority directorship on its board. The fact is, of course, that since the since 1 July last there have been 19 new carrier licences issued. None of those are subject to foreign ownership restrictions. There are literally hundreds of service providers running around the country these days. We have got a very deregulated environment. You want to put lead in the saddlebags of the third biggest player in the market; that is what you want to do. You want to make life very difficult for themâ

talk.start.para: âWe issued licences on the basis of majority Australian ownership; that was our position in government and we are sticking to it.
âOrder! Senator Schacht, you have had your opportunity to speak.
âThere is no need to go back into the history of thisâI would if the occasion required it. But all you need to do is focus on the immediate effect of your support for the Democrats.

speech.para: I do not expect the Democrats to know much better on this issue. Senator Allison put it very eloquently when she said, `We have a very old fashioned view.' In other words, the Democrats are really the ultimate conservatives when it comes to foreign ownership issues. They play the card for all its worth. They are not really interested in whether the world has changed, whether it is a global marketplace, whether companies are competing around the world, and whether Australia suffers very significantly in economic terms by having rigid foreign ownership restrictions. If you want to be another Albaniaâgo for it. But you pay the penalty for standards of living as a result. I know you cannot help yourselves on the issue. It is one of those things that keeps you marginally relevant for a small section of the population, so perhaps we should not expect any better.

But we certainly should expect more from Labor. I can understand why Senator Schacht wants to pretend that somehow this has got nothing to do with the analogue phaseout because Labor, of course, is acutely embarrassed on that whole issue. There are others running around the countryside trying to pretend that by ripping up those binding written agreements, exposing the government and therefore the taxpayer to lawsuits of potentially billions of dollars, and establishing the most appalling sovereign risk for the future, you would somehow solve Labor's problem.

The fact is that this motion has been put forward by the Democrats to try to capitalise on some very understandable concerns about the current quality of digital. We have taken a number of steps to try to redress that as best we can. The Labor Party basically wants to keep its head in the sand and hope that particular issue goes away. But as far as the government is concerned, to support this motion as Labor has now doneânailed its colours to the mastâsimply shows that it cannot be trusted. It is not interested in encouraging foreign ownership. Indeed, it seeks to specifically penalise companies such as Vodafone and sets an appalling precedent if we are to try to encourage others to come here and provide the level of competition which we are all confident will lead to lower prices and better quality of service. If you want to see one of the major players fundamentally disadvantaged and effectively encouraged to pack up and go home, then you are going the right way about it.
Question resolved in the negative.
