Motion (by Senator Minchin) proposed:
That the committee agrees to the amendments made by the House of Representatives.

talk.start.para: âLabor is supporting the amendments. They are of a very minor technical nature. But they are very important, nevertheless, in that they do ensure that the correct name of the ballast water research and development fund is, in fact, a reserve. I understand that is to meet the requirements of section 20 of the Financial Management and Accountability Act.

speech.para: We have been discussing, in the area of fisheries, the very important issue of ensuring our marine environment. Ballast water is a major environmental problem around the world. There was a debate on this issue in the Senate on a previous occasion. But very simply I would say that there are 154 million tonnes of ballast water coming into Australian waters each year. It does pose a significant environmental threat that has been recognised worldwide. We have had the introduction of exotic pests into Australian waters, including those of my own home state. Daria, seaweed from Japan, has become a major problem. There is the starfish problem we have in Tasmanian waters. There also are a number of other unwanted pests that have come into Australian waters around other parts of Australia which do represent a major environmental problem.

This legislation, Ballast Water Research and Development Funding Levy Collection Bill 1997, is important in establishing a proper research and development fund via a levy. It was a Labor initiative. When in government we did have a ballast water research committee. Initially the approach was to give the industry some time, two years, to attempt a voluntary contribution for ballast water research and development. That had a number of shortcomings. Fortunately the more responsible companies operating shipping lines did supply sufficient and significant funding, but an irresponsible few did not contribute to the levels that were required.

So, in the interests of fairness and to ensure a sufficient levy and that all who contribute to the problem of ballast water do make a fair and equitable contribution, a levy approach has been adopted. The government is to be congratulated for that approach.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 30 March, on motion by Senator Vanstone:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThe opposition will be supporting this important Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1998 . After all, of course, the bill proposes a range of amendments of mainly a technical or administrative nature for electoral administration and operational procedures in the conduct of elections and referendums. I note also that the majority of the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters have not been addressed in the legislation that is before the chamber today.

speech.para: The government also has before the Senate a second piece of legislation on this matter, the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 . It addresses a range of other recommendations, and other matters, of the joint standing committee. In some cases, of course, they are far more controversial than the ones we are dealing with in the legislation before us now. In relation to the second bill, the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 , I made it clear yesterday that it is the view of the opposition that the government is being unreasonable in bringing that bill before the Senate in such short time frame, given that it has just been introduced.

I believe that many of the provisions in the bill require a great deal of detailed consideration. That is why the opposition is keen to see the bill referred to the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee for consideration. Also, we do not support the government's proposal that the bill not be subject to standing order 111, that it be exempted from that standing order. Nevertheless, that is a matter that is in the hands of the Senate.

On behalf of the opposition, I will flag some amendments that the opposition may consider moving in the committee stage. As I have said, the opposition supports the substance of the bill, and I think I have made that position very clear. However, we may be utilising the committee stage of the bill to move amendments to close the apparent loophole in the Electoral Act that, in relation to the Greenfields Foundation, the Liberal Party has so expertly exploited over recent times.

The Liberal Party has been sidestepping the disclosure provisions of the Electoral Act. It is stock-in-trade for the Liberal Party. We are pretty used to thatâthe Liberal Party does so for the most partisan or base of party political considerations. We believe that this may well be a very useful vehicle and a very good opportunity for us to address this issue. On behalf of the Labor Party, I have, for quite a long time now, made our position on this serious situation very clear. I consider this to be a massive and indefensible rort and I have made that view known in the Senate on more than one occasion.

I want to be generous in my remarksâI am noted for it in speeches like thisâso let me be generous and acknowledge that the government has shown a willingness to negotiate on this particular matter.

talk.start.para: âOf course.

âI thought you would be happy with that. The government has had certain amendments drawn up to address recommendation 10 of the Australian Electoral Commissions's funding and disclosure report: election 1996, regarding associated entities. I am not sure, even at this point, whether it is the government's intention to pursue their own draft amendments in the committee stage on this bill. I am sorry that I am not clear on that matter. I can see that Senator Minchin is nodding so that means it is the government's intention to do that. I appreciate that information. That will be helpful in progressing down the track of closing this apparent loophole in the act.

speech.para: The AEC's funding and disclosure report identifies that there are some areas of dispute in the wording of the act's definition of associated entities and that these should not be allowed to become sources of confusion or loopholes. To date, the Australian Electoral Commission has relied upon the cooperation of organisations in engaging in discussions as to their status as associated entities. However, there are some cases where the AEC has been unable to determine whether an entity should disclose as an associated entityâin other words, whether an organisation should use those provisions of the act to disclose as an associated entity.

There is currently nothing that prevents an organisation from simply claiming that they do not meet the definition of an associated entity, and there is currently nothing that would prevent them from refusing to supply any justification for that particular stance. What I have been saying now for quite some time is that this is precisely what the Greenfields Foundation has done. They have deliberately exploited an apparent loophole in the definition of associated entity by basically writing back to the AEC informing the AEC that they do not consider themselves to be an associated entity. Of course, they do not supply adequate information to justify that stance. In fact, there is an enormous amount of evidence that I been able to present to the Senate in a number of contributions that shows how strong those particular links are.

Given the connections of the Greenfields Foundation to the Liberal Party and to the Free Enterprise Foundation, we say it is essential that the Australian Electoral Com mission investigate the Greenfields Foundation to ascertain whether or not they qualify as an associated entity. At the moment it is a matter for the AEC, of course, and apparently they do not feel that there is enough evidence to warrant such an investigation. I recall that during the most recent round of estimates hearings the AEC claimedâlet me use their words:
We had no authority in the act to go behind a separate foundation on the basis of any suspicion that we may have.
They are not my words. That is evidence presented by an officer of the Australian Electoral Commission to a Senate estimates committee hearing.

They have conceded that they may be able to pursue the Greenfields Foundation after a regular compliance audit of the federal Liberal Party. However, there is a very great weakness in that also because that might just take a couple of years to come around. So I do welcome the amendments that have been drawn up by the AEC to broaden and strengthen the investigative powers they have in dealing with and determining whether or not an organisation is an associated entity. I also welcome the fact that the minister at the table has indicated that he is proposing in the committee stages of this bill to progress those amendments.

At first blush, it would seem that those amendments are sufficient for the purposes of broadening the investigative powers of the AEC in pursuing suspected associated entities. For that reason I believe, given the drafts that have been kindly made available to the opposition, that they would receive support from the opposition and that they are worthy of support from the Senate committee.

The problem is that they still do not prevent the Liberal Party of Australia from using a vehicle like the Greenfields Foundation, or the Greenfields Foundation as it now exists, in effectively deliberately rorting the disclosure provisions of the Electoral Act. They do not close the apparent loophole. That is the problem with them: not that they are not good amendments as far as they go, from what I have seen; they just do not go far enough.

Our concern in the Labor Partyâand I hope it is a concern that will be shared by Senator Murray, who has been taking a close interest in these issues, and by other minor party and Independent senators in the chamberâis that the Greenfields Foundation will still try to claim that they are not an associated entity, despite the obvious and transparent strong links they have to the Liberal Party and the Free Enterprise Foundation; that they will try to get around the current definition of associated entityânamely, an organisation that `operates wholly or mainly for the benefit of one or more registered political parties'. That is the current definition. They try and get around that definition by saying that the foundation will also be making significant contributions to unspecified charities, or some other rouse that the Liberal Party would be capable of using.

We will be proposing amendments that tighten the definition of associated entity by altering the definition to read that it `operates wholly or to a significant extent for the benefit of one or more registered political parties'. Hopefully, that will go further down the track of closing that apparent loophole that has been exploited by the Liberal Party through the loan from the Greenfields Foundation.

We also need to amend the act to change the disclosure periods so that in the event that the Greenfields loan is forgiven, thus becoming a gift, its donors must still be disclosed even if the gift is outside the same disclosure period as the original donations. We want to try and make sure that the act is as watertight as it can be as far as this money laundering exercise is concerned. We would like to see the act amended to prevent loans being received from anyone other than a financial institution, unless certain disclosure provisions are met, such as detailing the terms and conditions of the loan. This effectively would have the impact of preventing an organisation such as the Greenfields Foundation giving a loan to the Liberal Party with very favourable conditions that may actually make it a gift or, indeed, a loan that is forgiven at a later dateâa loan that need never be repaid.

These are just some of the concerns of opposition. We have indicated that we are happy to continue to negotiate on what I consider are very important matters. I understand that Senator Minchin is desperately keen to see this legislation dealt with as quickly as possible so he can try to ram the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1998 through the Senate. One almost believes that there must be an ulterior motive for this alacrity on his part. Perhaps there is even a suggestion that there might soon be an election.

As far as the Labor Party is concerned, as Senator Conroy would be aware, the integrity of the act and these processes has always been of the utmost importance to the Australian Labor Party. We intend to fight tooth and nail to ensure that there are adequate, thorough and proper disclosure provisions to prevent this extraordinary abuse, manipulation and deliberate flouting of the disclosure provisions of the Electoral Act that has been the Liberal Party's deliberate intent through this vehicle of the Greenfields Foundation.

I suppose you have to say that the Liberal Party has a lot of experience in exploiting apparent loopholes in the Electoral Act. I would have to say to Senator Minchin that he has a lot of form in this regard. I am sure that senators would recall that, up until 1995, it was the Free Enterprise Foundation that was the vehicle used to launder funds through donations of massive sums to the coalition without ever disclosing or revealing where those funds originally came from.

Of course, the then Labor government, desperately trying to keep up with these rorts that were being perpetrated by the Liberal Partyâthe latest attempt to sleaze and sneak around the disclosure provisions of the actâthe then Labor government amended the Electoral Act to close that loophole by determining that associated entities had to disclose their source of funds. That resulted in a crackdown on disclosures in 1995. The Free Enterprise Foundation was required to disclose any new donations it received. Now you have a mechanism whereby the Greenfields Foundation provides a loan. We do not know what the terms and conditions of the loan are, but it provides a loan to the Liberal Partyâ

talk.start.para: âThey are sweet.

âSenator Murray may know more than I. They do not smell very sweet to me, I have to say, Senator Murray. This stinks. This really stinks. I am sure that, if you thought about it, Senator Murray, you would agree. Unfortunately, I probably do not have a great deal of time. It is one of those occasions when you would like a second reading speech not to be 20 minutes, but an hour and 20 minutes, so we would have an opportunity to explain to the Senate in great detail about how this manipulation has taken place. I will use the committee stage of this bill to provide the Senate, in the public interest, with a very detailed exposition and explanation of how badly the Liberal Party of Australia has deliberately manipulated the disclosure provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. (Time expired)

âThe Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1998 is the first of two pieces of legislation which the government has brought forward as a result of the report of the inquiry into the conduct of the 1996 federal election and as a result of the government's response to that report.

speech.para: Senator Minchin is a former esteemed member of that committee. Senator Faulkner is a current esteemed member of that committee, and I am just a modest ordinary member. That means that all three of us have some intimate knowledge of what is before us. The bill before us is by and large a technical bill. That being so, overall it will get the support of the Australian Democrats, but we do intend to move a number of amendments to it, not the raft of amendments that we would like to move to the act as a whole arising out of our recommendations to the report, but certainly those which are immediate and relevant to this bill. The second bill is more controversial, covering as it does matters of donations and matters of rights of prisoners to vote, on both of which we have a great number of concerns.

The amendments we propose to this bill have already been circulated and relate to the question of how to vote, which has always been a vexed question for the Australian Democrats, and indeed for all participants in elections. You might recall the case of Evans v. Crichton-Browne, which was relevant in that area. There are amendments which relate to the loss of privacy intentions in this bill and to what we would loosely describe as Langer amendments.

One issue which was raised, at some length, by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) is an issue that is dear to our hearts. I can assure Senator Faulkner that we will follow his proposed amendment very carefully, because it is proper and important that full disclosure of the source of donations is made so that we can ensure that our political parties are not subject to improper influence or the attempted purchase of favours in return for very large sums being concealed.

We did make a recommendation in our minority report which probably went a little further. We recommended that political parties which received donations from trusts or foundations must be obliged to return or forfeit the money donated unless the following were disclosed: a declaration of beneficial and ultimate control of the trust estate, including by trustees; a declaration of the identities of the beneficiaries of the trust estate including, in the case of individuals, their countries of residence, and, in the case of beneficiaries which are not individuals, their countries of incorporation or registration, as the case may be; details of any relationships with other entities; the percentage distribution of income within the trust; and any changes during the donations year in relation to the information provided above.

But the issue that Senator Faulkner draws attention to is loansâloans which may be, as I describe them, somewhat more than commercial loans, namely, sweet loans; loans which may have preferential terms such as that they never need to be repaid or may have extraordinary interest rates below the rate of proper commercial return or, indeed, not existing at all. It is definitely an area which needs to be tidied up. People who participate in our political system need to be congratulated; we need to encourage people to donate money voluntarily to political parties. But they need to do so on an above board basis, on a clear, open and transparent basis, so that the community as a whole, and all political parties, can be satisfied as to both motives and source.

Three areas are going to be dealt with by us in relation to this billâhow-to-votes, privacy and what I would refer to as the Langer amendments. The Australian Democrats are not supporters of optional preferential voting. The introduction of sections 272, 329(3) and 329A of the Commonwealth Electoral Act were intended to protect people who made an inadvertent error in casting their vote. Unfortunately, the beneficial effect of these sections is now being undermined by the deleterious effects of special pleadings. As an increasing number of citizens wilfully defy the law by encouraging voters to use a form of optional preferential voting using those sections in the Electoral Act, the AEC has felt itself obliged to launch injunctions and/or prosecutions during an election period. That is a matter to be regretted.

At the 1996 federal election, 48,979 exhausted votes for the House of Representatives were saved from informality by section 270. This was despite the Albert Langer campaign, which was an offence under the Electoral Act, advocating the use of section 329A as a means of achieving a form of optional preferential voting. Although the exhausted votes cast in such a manner represent only 0.4 per cent of the total number of votesâI should point out that that number of votes would easily get a couple of members of parliament returnedâthe cost to the Electoral Commission in pursuing citizens who break the law by advocating the practice of exhausting one's votes is an unnecessary burden. I, for one, do not like the thought of the Electoral Commission having to pursue citizens anyway, on that basis.

We do not support the advocacy of informal voting. We, therefore, have supported the government's recommendation to close off that area of the law being used as a loophole. However, we think the government has not gone far enough, in that the practice is still possible in voting for the Senate. We have proposed some amendments to make the Senate practices consistent with those for the House of Representatives.

The other issue which I will touch on briefly is privacy. Recommendation 52 of the majority report seeks to provide gender, age and salutation details to members of parliament and registered political parties. The Australian Democrats believe that the provision of elector information, such as the gender and age details of constituents, intrudes unnecessarily into the privacy of constituents, given that this information is not necessary for official purposes and would serve no public interest benefit. I am aware, of course, as a member of the committee, that there are some states which allow this. Nevertheless, we do not support it.

It is not the Australian Electoral Commission's or the public's role to provide this level of campaigning detail to sitting members of parliament or to their political parties, and the majority report's recommendation would have the effect of providing public resources to boost incumbency. In addition, the information which this recommendation seeks contravenes the right to privacy by citizens. The Privacy Commissioner has not supported the provision of gender, age and salutation details to members of parliament, and neither do we.

Accordingly, the Australian Democrats, when the matter is before the Senate, will oppose any intention to intrude into the privacy protections presently provided by the act. I hope that we would get the non-government senators to support us in that matter. We think that the recommendation encroaches on the independence of the AEC by requiring it to collect and pass on to parliamentary incumbents, using public resources, valuable campaigning details and material. We do not think that the public interest is served by the provision of this information. No survey has been made of a representative sample of electors, as far as I am aware, to establish whether they themselves would be willing to have these details provided to parliamentarians. The lack of such a survey is a problem. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. I ask: is the minister aware that prior to 1 May the 4,000 jobless in Cessnock had access to a highly successful and well-regarded employment service with 10 staff in Cessnock? Can the minister explain why it is that since 1 May these 4,000 unemployed now have to wait in line to have their case dealt with by one of five staff in that service or pay a $7 bus fare to Maitland in order to get assistance to find a new job? Where is the benefit of the government's new job network promise to the people of Cessnock and where is the second employment service provider that was promised to Cessnock? Why is it that there are six employment services in Maitlandâa marginal seatâand only one in Cessnockâa safe Labor seat?

âIn answer to Senator West's question, in the Hunter and on the north coast we have 16 job network providers for job matching, that is, for people who are looking for work; we have seven for job search training, which is the next layer of assistance; and we have eight for intensive assistance. I will remind the Senate that intensive assistance relates to those people who are disadvantaged, such as the long-term unemployed and people such as migrants and indigenous people. In the Hunter and on north coast we have eight such job providers. We have five new apprenticeship centres just for that area.
âAnswer the question!

âThis relates squarely to the question. We are talking about improved opportunities for job seekers; improved facilities under this new scheme which we have brought in. In New South Wales we have 491 sites, compared with 100 CES sites that were previously there.
âHow many was that?

âIn answer to Senator Kemp's question, that is 491 new sites compared with 100 old ones. I would say to Senator West that what we have provided the people of New South Wales withâand particularly those of regional New South Walesâis more facilities, more opportunities and more assistance for those people who are long-term unemployed and disadvantaged.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. First of all, I wonder if the minister is aware of size of the Hunter and the north coast. I am talking about 4,000 people in Cessnock who have five employment service staff to take care of their needs, otherwise they have to face a $7 bus fare to Maitland. Given that this is the third day in a row I have asked questions about specific employment service facilities for people in rural New South Wales, will the minister please undertake to draw Minister Kemp's attention as a matter of urgency to the dissatisfaction of the people in rural New South Wales with the employment services being offered to them under the government's new Jobs Network?

âThe only dissatisfaction was with Labor's previous performance when it was in government. The only dissatisfaction was with the high levels of unemployment when youth unemployment peaked at over 30 per cent. What they were dissatisfied with were the high rates of unemployment which we saw under the previous Labor government and which peaked at about 11 per cent, as I recallâa far cry from the 7.9 per cent that we have at the moment. I remind the opposition to look at what it did when it was in government for 13 years, or more appropriately, what it did not do.

âMy question is to the Minister for Justice. Has the minister's attention been drawn to an article in this morning's Daily Telegraph entitled, `Police deny role in Skase bungle', which reported that the former Labor Attorney-General, Michael Lavarch, said that at no time was he made aware of the passport renewal application and its subsequent granting. Is this comment consistent with the former Senator Evans's personal explanation to the parliament just two days ago?

âI thank Senator Ferris for the question. Yes, my attention was drawn to the Daily Telegraph article today entitled, `Police deny role in Skase bungle.' My attention was drawn to the statements of former Attorney-General, Michael Lavarch. What the former Attorney-General is doing is clearly distancing himself from Labor's massive bungle on Skase. He is making it quite clear that he was not consulted. He has cut the rope on Senator Bolkus; he has cut the rope on Gareth Evans and said, `I was not a part of this bungle.' Mr Lavarch has directly contradicted the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

answer.para: In a personal explanation in the other House on Tuesday Gareth Evans said he recollected talking to Lavarch about Skase's passport. He said:
. . . I do have a general recollection of discussing the issue with the Attorney-General, Michael Lavarch, with whom I discussed many aspects of Skase affair, and getting advice from him. . .
Mr Lavarch says that this is not the case; the issue was not raised with him.

Labor's explanation is like something from the Goon Show with former Senator Evans saying, `I recall talking to you' and Michael Lavarch saying, `I didn't talk to anyone about this.' It is a bit like pass the parcel. It is a bungle and no-one wants to take responsibility for it. The responsibility clearly rests with the former Minister for Foreign Affairs.

I have checked with my department and they have no record of Michael Lavarch advising Mr Evans about issuing Skase with a passport. So this is a new twist on Labor's old theme of `not responsible'. Senators will remember Carmen Lawrence who got out of her bungles by saying that she could not recall things that did happen. Mr Evans has another way of doing it; he recalls things that did not happen and, in any event, tries to get himself out of it.

The point is that Michael Lavarch did not offer advice. Gareth Evans is simply trying to blame other people for his own bungling. His behaviour is a disgrace. The former foreign minister must come clean and give a full and proper explanation of how Skase got a brand new 10-year passport.

First of all he said, `The law made me do it. I had no choice', and poor old Senator Bolkus was supporting him in thisâ`The law made me do it. I had no choice.' Now we know that is not correct. We know that is just not true. Now Mr Evans must explain why he did not get legal advice before renewing the passport. He must explain why the passport was issued so quickly when there was no rush. This man was too sick to travel, but we rushed a passport through and he already had a valid passport.

Former Senator Evans could have ensured that he and his department considered every option, especially when the issue of arrest warrants was imminent. They could have ensured that. He must explain why Skase was given a brand spanking new passport until 1999.

Yesterday, Senator Bolkus interjected that we should get some good legal advice. It is, of course, now apparent that Labor in power never got legal advice about the reissue of the passport, so Senator Bolkus should not be telling us to get advice. When they were in power they never got the advice.
Senator Bolkus interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Bolkus says, `Ignorance of the law is no excuse.' What we want to know is: what is his excuse? What excuse does he offer?

answer.para: Mr Evans must now tell the Australian people why, with all his self-claimed skill, with all his self-claimed intelligence and with all the resources of his department, the sanctimonious then senator gave Mr Skase a 10-year valid Australian passport.

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. I ask the minister how he responds to the criticisms of the new Job Network by Perth South Metropolitan Youth Link Chief Executive, Sam Gowegati, who has described the new system as an `inefficient, confusing fiasco'? Why is it that Perth pool shop owner Stephen Bell had to try for a week to find an employment agency to help him fill a vacancy? Why is it that Shane Francis of Kwinana had to travel to Mirrabooka for an interview at a job agency to apply for a job in Midland whereas, under the old CES system, he could have applied for that job near his home in Kwinana?

âAs I understand it, Employment National has provision for job seekers in Rockingham which, as Senator McKiernan would know, is adjacent to or just nearby Kwinana. I would have to check those facts.

answer.para: But, in relation to the question about Job Network in Western Australia, I think it is worthwhile remembering that previously there were 29 CES sites; under the new arrangement there are now 142. We have gone from 29 to 142 sites. I do not think that is too bad. As Senator McKiernan would know, Western Australia is a state of two million square kilometresâa very big state indeed. What would be of great benefit is having a greater number of sites.

talk.start.para: âWhat about Karratha?

âI heard somebody say, `What about Karratha?' I can tell you that there is a fee-for-service arrangement for Karratha because Karratha is one of the few areas we did not get a tender for. I think it was Senator Chris Evans who said that. I can say to Senator Chris Evans that there are special arrangements in hand for Karratha and they are being attended to. I think Senator Eggleston has been working on this. He is a senator from the north-west who has been of great assistance to the government in this regard. I would say that Jobs Network is working very well in Western Australia. We have gone from 29 sites to 142.

answer.para: With respect to that other aspect that Senator McKiernan raisedâtravel to MirrabookaâI would have to check on that.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for saying he will check on the situation where a person travelled from Kwinana to Mirrabooka to get a job in Midland. Minister, you missed the point I made in the first part of the question when I asked about Sam Gowegati who has claimed the new system is an `efficient, confusing fiasco'. I assume you are accepting those criticisms. Do you agree with Mr Peter Storey, the Managing Director of Employment National, that Employment National should not be copping the blame for everything the Commonwealth Employment Service does not do any more? Isn't it the government that should be copping the blame for that system rather than Employment National?

âOne thing I note from Senator McKiernan's question is that he cites a comment by someone that this is confusing, but he does not say why. We do not hear why. It would be of great assistance to know why he thinks it is. I say to you, Senator McKiernan, that when we introduce a reform of great magnitude which offers the unemployed of Australia great opportunities, we have a task to get the message across. I would have thought you would have been keen to tell us why this person thought it was confusing. I put to you, Senator McKiernan, that I would have to check on that as well.

answer.para: We have had an overwhelming response that the Jobs Network system is working, and that it is working very well. I say to you that, if you look at the Herald Sun, you will see that the headlines are: `Rush to Salvos new job service'. That is what the Salvation Army is saying about its provision of a service to those people. If I were Senator McKiernan, I would look at that. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask if Senator Hill is aware of the new found enthusiasm of the Labor leader in Queensland to legislate in favour of the Wik legislation the moment he gets into office? While there are great advantages for Queensland in this, is this is a new age of responsibility for the Labor Party? Can we expect Senator Faulkner to move a recision motion to resubmit the Wik legislation or is it just the usual Janus-faced approach, dripping with sincerity, of Labor Party policy?

question.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI understand you want Senator Minchin to answer the question. Senator Minchin can answer the question.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Hill for referring the question from Senator MacGibbon to me. I do not normally pay much attention to what state Labor leaders say.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senators on my left will cease shouting.

âBut I must say that in this case I was fascinated to hear what Queensland Labor leader, Peter Beattie, had to say about the government's 10-point plan to fix Paul Keating's Native Title Act. Instead of what we normally get from the federal Labor Party, a great diatribe about how terrible our legislation is, Mr Beattie deliberately chose to say that he will work with the proposed legislationâin the unlikely event that he should be elected at the Queensland election.

answer.para: You have got to remember this: Mr Beattie had a choice. He could have joined with Mr Beazley and the federal Labor Party and gone into a mindless rant about how terrible our legislation was, but he did not do that. He deliberately chose to say that, if he was elected, he would work with the federal government's legislation should it be passed following a double dissolution.

There is a very important point to remember here: if Mr Beattie is electedâand that is very unlikely, I hopeâhe is not bound to implement the 10-point plan. Our legislation is enabling legislation; it enables the states to engage in certain things and approve certain future acts. He is not bound to do so, but he has said today that he will. He has completely abandoned the federal Labor Party's position on this issue. He has completely abandoned where the Labor Party stands. He knows the federal Labor Party's approach is completely unrealistic, unworkable and untenable in the state of Queensland and, facing his election, he has abandoned your position.

Of course we know that Mr Beazley privately thinks that too. We know from your leaked Labor minutes that he has issued an edict to all federal Labor members that if they dare to venture north of the New South Wales border they have got to talk to Mr Wayne Swan about what they can say about native title. I spent a couple of weeks with Wayne Swan in the United States once and I know exactly what Mr Swan actually thinks about the federal Labor Party's hopeless position on native title and how completely untenableâ

talk.start.para: âWhy don't you talk to Malcolm Fraser about One Nation preferences?
âOrder! The level of intervention is far too high and shouting across the chamber is disorderly.

âMr Beazley knows as well as Mr Beattie that the federal Labor position on the Native Title Act is untenable in Queensland. Frankly, Mr Beattie, as a Labor leader facing an election, has given the federal Labor leader a complete slap in the face on this important legislation. He has said that Mr Beazley's position is a complete lead balloon in the state of Queensland and, frankly, it just completely destroys the federal Labor Party'sâ
âWhat does Malcolm Fraser say?
âOrder! Senator Faulkner, shouting across the chamber is totally disorderly and I will not tolerate it.

âMr Beattie's statements over the last 24 hours supporting the federal government's 10-point plan completely destroy the credibility of Mr Beazley's attacks on our bill. He has completely undermined the federal Labor Party's position. Federal Labor knows that its position is unacceptable to the people of Queensland and, of course, Mr Beattie has said he can work with it.

answer.para: We all know what Bob Carr thinks of this legislation. The Premier of New South Wales has made it quite clear that he basically supports the 10-point plan, and I think you could bet your bottom dollar that if there was an election in Western Australia in the imminent future, Dr Gallop, the Labor leader in Western Australia, would abandon the federal Labor Party's position just as fast as Mr Beattie has.

The left of the Labor Party have lumbered the Labor Party with a position that is completely unacceptable to rural and regional Australia, and, of course, that has now been abandoned by Mr Beattie. The federal Labor position absolutely reeks of double standards. The Labor Party says it wants a tougher registration test, but you voted in here to water it down. You say you want certainty, but you voted to subject the Native Title Act to the Racial Discrimination Act and opposed a sunset clause. You say you want fairness and equity, but you voted to discriminate against farmers on their own land. Federal Labor's position would be a complete disaster for the people of Queensland and Mr Beattie knows it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer. Can the minister confirm that the Prime Minister's 1997 greenhouse statement included a mandatory requirement that by 2010 an additional two per cent of electricity will be resourced from renewable energy sources, and that there was no limitation to grid-based applications? Is it true that a meeting on was held Thursday 14 May, this year, between senior advisers from Senator Parer's and Senator Hill's offices and key industry groups in the industry greenhouse network? Is it also the case that this meeting agreed on the proposal from the industry groups to water down the Prime Minister's commitment to apply only to grid-based applications, effectively benefiting users in remote areas, such as mining companies? Is the Prime Minister aware that these two ministers have weakened his greenhouse commitments in this way, and if he does not know yet, when do the ministers plan to tell him?

âThere is a discussion paper which is out and my suggestion to you, Senator, is to go and read it. As I understand it, the discussion paper reflects the commitment by the Prime Minister in regard to the two per cent renewables. I have nothing further to add to that. I was not present at the meeting.

âI ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, perhaps you could take on notice the first part of the question. But can you confirm that the membership of the industry greenhouse network includes most major mining companies in Australia and peak bodies such as the Queensland Mining Council, which represents the Queensland coal industry, and operating mines such as Jellinbah? Can the minister also confirm that this decision will save mining companies significant amounts in their operating expenditure and will continue mining companies' total reliance on fuel such as diesel rather than encouraging a move to renewable energy? Minister, isn't this decision to weaken the Prime Minister's commitments another example of Minister Parer doing a special deal to further his temporarily quarantined interests in the mining and fossil fuel industries and another example of Minister Parer's blatant conflicts of interest?
âSenator Parer, there are matters within that supplementary question that are relevant to your department; but others are not.

âThe words of a past senior minister in the Labor Party who said the Labor Party had no understanding of the mining industry come forward so clearly in this particular instance. As regards the coal industryâand I am thinking right around the whole of Australiaâto my knowledge there is not one coal mine in the whole of Australia that is not connected to the grid network. They are all connected to the grid network. You might have learned something from that, Senator. Of course, the whole thrust of the two per cent renewablesâ
âAll mines?

âAll coal mines are connected to the grid network. You are running some sort of interesting line that somehow they are not. Certainly, if you are looking at the gold mining industry, and as Senator Cook will know because he comes from that area, there are some that are not. Certainly they generate power using diesel. And, of course, there are some mines in the Northern Territory, but they are certainly not coal mines.(Time expired)

âMy question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, you were ordered by the Senate, upon my motion, to table certain documents by last Monday relating to the waterfront dispute. Minister, do you recall that on Monday you gave an equivocal response? Minister, are you aware that the Democrats thought it was reasonable to agree to an informal extension to today, in line with a request from the office of the government leader that the government needed more time in order to table the documents? With regard to the extension, I am surprised that there is still no sign of these documents today. I therefore ask you, minister: when will you table these documents, as you have been ordered to do so by a motion of the Senate, and will you do so?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI am not aware that I gave an equivocal response last Monday. I am aware of what Senator Murray said by way of misunderstanding in the first instance and subsequent clarification. I will be in a position after question time to say something further on the matter.

âI ask a supplementary question. Minister, I am advised that, if a minister of the crown does not provide such documents as requested, the only recourse left to the Senate would be to have you not heard in your capacity as a minister in the chamber. My question is as follows, Minister: do you accept that the only recourse, if you do not provide the documents, is for the Senate to seek support for an order that you be not heard in your capacity as a minister for the rest of the session until and unless you table these documents or until you satisfy the Senate with your reasons for not doing so?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI want to know whether there would be a reduction in pay, Madam President. I find that a very intimidating suggestion. I can imagine that a lot of others might get some temporary satisfaction from such an outcome, but I will not take that as a direct threat, of course. I will take it simply as light-hearted banter. I am sure that in a time of need I will have sufficient friends to enable me to continue to treat your questions in the manner that they deserve. All I can say to you is that I am sure there are endless possibilities. I hope you have a lot of fun exploring them. Whatever you would like to do by way of prejudging any answer that might be given will obviously be, no doubt, a subject of further discussion in the Democrat party room. I know that you do not often get your way there but I am sure that on this occasion there will be more than enough people coming to my aid. I therefore look forward to being able to answer very many more questions and take very many more bills through this chamber.

âMy question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Does the minister stand by the documents he tabled in the Senate in late March, namely the letter he wrote to the Prime Minister outlining actions he proposed to take in relation to his conflict of interests and his amended statement of pecuniary interest? Is the minister aware that these documents tabled in parliament are contradicted by the minister's former fellow shareholder in Queensland Coal Mines Management, Mr Robert Adams? Is it not the case that Mr Adams has revealed a dividend stream from QCMM to the minister totalling at least $1.3 million over four years, including during the time the minister had portfolio responsibility for resources matters? Is it not also the case that Mr Adams has revealed the use of a tax manipulation device, namely QCMM making non-taxable loans to shareholders in lieu of paying income in the form of taxable dividends, while the minister was chairman of directors?

âI completely stand by the letter that was tabled in this place and that has become public knowledge. The details are there in the letter for everyone to see. I have no comment to make. They are exactly correct.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister to explain the contradictions between documents that he tabled in the Senate in March of this year, including the letter he wrote to the Prime Minister which outlined the actions that he as minister proposed to take in relation to his conflict of interest, and his amended statement of pecuniary interestâdocuments that stand in his nameâand what has been revealed by a former fellow shareholder in Queensland Coal Mines Management, Mr Robert Adams.
âSenator Parer, you should only deal with matters that relate to your portfolio.

âMadam President, I rise on a point of order. This question goes to the fact that Senator Parer has tabled documents in the Senate which include a letter that he wrote to the Prime Minister in relation to issues the opposition had raisedâ

interjection.para: Government senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senators on my right!
âThose documents, which he tabled in the Senate, went to the issue of conflict of interest and an amended statement of pecuniary interest.
âWhat is the point of order?
âMy point of order to you, Madam Presidentâ

interjection.para: Government senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenators on my right will cease interjecting. It is important that I hear what is being said.

âThank you, Madam President. The point of order is this: that is of direct relevance to all of this minister's responsibility as resources minister. I would submit to you, Madam President, that there is nothing in the question or supplementary question that has been asked of this Minister for Resources that could possibly be ruled out of order. It goes to the conduct of his ministerial responsibilities and a contradiction of what Mr Adams is saying.

âMy original ruling was that the minister should answer those matters that relate to his portfolio. If you are suggesting that they all do, it will be a matter for the minister to deal with the question as he sees fit.

âOne of the things this minister knowsâhe has tried this over and over againâand that the Leader of the Opposition knows is that at no stage in the administration of my portfolio has there ever been a conflict of interest, nor the potential for a conflict of interest.
âWhat about what Adams is saying?

âSenator Faulkner might listen, but he won't, will he? He has predetermined his ideas. There was no suggestion at any time that the family trust that I was part of did not get dividends. Of course it got dividends. Senator Faulkner is really thick. The point was made. In the whole time that I have been a minister in this government I have never ever been a nominated beneficiary.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, your government has consistently said there are no problems in child care. In Queensland there certainly are. Over the past month I have visited a number of private child-care centres on the Sunshine Coast, in Brisbane and in Cairns, which are, with occupancy rates between 40 and 70 per cent, now on the point of no longer being viable. With so many owners now telling meâsome in tearsâthat they are desperate to cut their losses and get out of child care altogether, Minister, what do I tell them? Minister, what do I tell these small businesses which are struggling as a direct result of your policies?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Woodley for the question. If I were Senator Woodley, I would tell them to write to Senator Crowley because what is occurring now is a legacy Labor left behind. Under the previous government, private child-care centres were established in locations with no direction or support from government to indicate areas of greatest need. There was haphazard growth all over the country. Too many centres now exist in certain areas and have created an oversupply, while other areas have a great needâan undersupply. This poorly planned access to child care has created uncertainty in the child-care industry and the very things that you have just pointed out, Senator Woodley. My answer to you, Senator Woodley, is to write to Senator Crowley.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, the problem is that two years ago all of those centres were viable, so something has happenedâand it is your policy. The coalition strongly opposed the introduction of accreditation for child-care centres. You opposed it at every opportunity. Are you aware that backyard, unregulated child care in Queenslandâa type of care that needs no accreditationâhas grown at the rate of 92 per cent over the last couple of years? Minister, aren't the government's child-care policies, which have put formal child care out of the reach of many families while encouraging the use of informal care, really just a backdoor way of getting rid of high quality accredited child care altogether?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer is no.

âMy question is also to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Has the minister's attention been drawn to the statement by Ms Robyn Monro Miller, the Chairperson of the National Out of School Hours Services Association, on Monday of this week, that, Australia wide, 66 outside school hours services have closed this year, each leaving 20 to 30 children aged between five and 12 without supervision? That is a total of 1,500 children. Is the minister aware that most of these centres have closed since the changes to funding, including the diverting of management subsidies into means tested child-care assistanceâthese changes having taken effect on 27 April? When will the government admit that its savage cuts to child care have had, and will continue to have, a devastating effect on Australian families?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Collins for the question. Once again we have the manipulation of figures and, in fact, the truth. Senator Collins ought to go and see the film Primary Colors , in which she might see Governor Jack Stanton in that film saying that he was going to do something unusual for a politicianâhe was going to tell the truth. I suggest that Senator Collins go and see that so that she could then know how to tell the truth.

answer.para: The National Out of School Hours Services Association recently stated that 66 out of school hours services have closed, which is what Senator Collins has just said. However, overall, those places have increased under the Howard government. There were 48,785 places in June 1995 under Labor.

talk.start.para: âHa! Ha!

âI will repeat that as Senator Crowley was cackling. There were 48,785 places in June 1995 under Labor, and 78,970 in June 1997 under this government. I would like Senator Collins to go back to the figures. The reforms actually assist low and middle income families. Funding to services is equivalent to the previous operational subsidy and continues until the end of June. There is $20 million in restructuring and transitional assistance, including training for all services, a help line for advice and individual assistance in the form of service visits. New financial support of $4.4 million per year has been provided to rural and remote and isolated services to ensure continuity of supply in these regions.

answer.para: Since the 1996 budget announcement to withdraw operational subsidy from community based long day care centres, 43 have closed as at 30 April 1998. However, there has been a net increase of 310 centres over the same period. So there has actually been an increase over the same period. The main causes of closures are ongoing financial and utilisation difficulties and the complete lack of planning measures by the former government. This government has introduced a new planning system to direct supply to areas of greatest need.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Since the minister is talking about the full picture and truth, perhaps the minister could tell us whether he knows what alternative arrangements have been made for the care of those 1,500 children whose centres have closed, or doesn't the minister care?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI have already stated the increase in the number of places that are available. As at 30 April 1998, 43 community based long day care centres which have received operational subsidy have closed since 1 July 1996. As at 30 April 1998, 50 new community based long day care centres had opened since 1 July 1996. They have opened for those 1,500â

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! There are far too many interjections.
âSenator Knowles is trying to straighten him out.
âSenator Knowles has been very helpful in providing additional information for Senator Collins's benefit.
âShe's fibbing!

âSenator Knowles has pointed out that under the previous government the number was 12 and under us it has gone up to 20, so that is hardly a decrease. I suggest that Senator Collins go and do one of those numeracy programs that Senator Allison was talking about the other day so that she can know how to add up.
âMy question is to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Artsâ

âI rise on a point of order, Madam President. You would be aware that Senator Harradine was next in line to ask a question. I think he will be here a little later, and I ask that his question then be put, if that is okay. If it is not going to be taken, I would be happy to take a question instead of his the next time around.
âOrder! That is not a point of order.

âMinister, you would be aware of a feature article in today's Australian entitled `The Full Monty', which details the proliferation of sex related programming on radio and television. Is the government concerned about this issue? What action is the government taking to ensure that the appropriate community standards are maintained?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âNot only the government but indeed I think the entire community is concerned about the proliferation of what seem to be increasingly prurient programs on both radio and television. In the article to which Senator Calvert refers, which is headed `The Full Monty', you could be forgiven for thinking that television and radio programmers have taken a dose of Viagra. As Amanda Meade reports, `Anything goes on the airwaves these days.' That is absolutely correct, and I have to say that I was shocked to read the extent to which some of these programs have descended. There has been concern in recent times about Playboy's Really Naked Truth No. 1 , which essentially showed nude women and men's reaction to them and justified it on the basis that the subject matter of the program was nudity, which I would have thought was, if anything, a tautology. It was simply an excuse to portray nudity for nudity's sake. As a result of those concerns, I have taken up the matter up with FACTS and I am told that the code will be amended to deal more strictly with the issue of nudity.

answer.para: When it comes to radio, this article makes it a matter of particular community concern to find that we can now have programs which have callers revealing their sexual exploits in lurid detail and guests stripping in the studio while the presenter gives a running commentary, giving away erotic messages and promoting brothels. Indeed, the presenter said that she was thrilled that she has finally being given the freedom to go all the way. She is very proud of the live broadcast she did from a brothel. She said, `We narrated it like it was a sports event. We knew we were really pushing the boundaries that time, but everyone wants to know what really goes on inside a brothel.' I do not think they do. There may well be some people who have a passing interest in titillation, but to suggest that somehow this is what people expect on radio at any hour of the day or night I think is completely misunderstanding the rules that are in place.
The self-regulation code of practice that is imposed by FARB is meant to contain this sort of behaviour because it reads:
A licensee shall not broadcast language which would offend to a substantial degree the contemporary standards of decency held by the audience of the station.

This particular radio station takes a view that there are no rules except to `keep the expletives down'. If that is the attitude, I would certainly expect the ABA to take action under its program standards, which require it, where it is satisfied that there is convincing evidence that a code of practice is not operating to provide appropriate community safeguards, to then determine a standard in relation to that matter. I think that article does raise a number of concerns.

In the area of television, with the change from AO to M and MA it is explicitly stated in the actâthe FACTS code of practice faithfully reflects thisâthat there should be no reduction in standards as a result of that changeover. But it would seem to me from a couple of these programs, particularly one called Sex/Life on Channel 10, that there are some who are taking the opportunity in that transition to substantially reduce the quality of these programs.

I am writing to the ABA pointing out the government's strong expectation that the television and radio codes should comply with parliament's expectation, stressing the need for the ABA to be vigilant. I am also writing to FACTS and FARB expressing the government's concern. I make it clear that we will not tolerate broadcasters pushing the envelope of the codes or not complying with them. I do not think anyone in this country wants to see an electronic version of Sodom and Gomorrah. It is unedifying and debasing, and we will take action to take ensure that it does not occur. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question without notice is to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Does the minister agree with the Premier of Victoria, Mr Kennett, that a state parliamentary inquiry into the ABC is required to investigate the so-called Sydney-centric bias in the management of the ABC? Will the minister be giving evidence before the inquiry? Will he explain that the reason for the reduced ABC services in Victoria is the minister's own $55 million a year cuts to the ABC budget? Is the inquiry all Mr Kennett's own work, or did the minister conspire with Mr Kennett to instigate an inquiry because he did not have the courage to conduct it himself?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âIf one puts aside the vituperation and the hatred embodied in that question, the answer is that it is Mr Kennett's own initiative. If Senator Carr spent a bit more time on reading the newspapers and less on branch stacking then he would see that there has been, in particular, an upper house backbencher who has been pursuing issues of the ABC's balance not only in terms of Victoria and New South Wales but also in ensuring proper coverage to regional areas. That committee will be reporting back in March of next year. I imagine that it will travel and take evidence very extensively.

answer.para: Senator Carr might be interested to know that even the MEAA expressed some support for the proposition, particularly given the ABC's decision to transfer the Between the Lines book program and another major arts program to Sydney for no apparent reason other than that they have a presenter there whom they prefer to front the program.

This is not an initiative of the federal government but we certainly understand why Mr Kennett would take such action. Indeed, my colleague Senator Kemp earned a living out of pursuing this issue some years ago and I think he did it very effectively. The ABC does have a charter obligation to provide proper national coverage.

I know the likes of Senator Carr do not really have much time to follow what goes on on ABC radio and television; they are more interested in the union machinations. Let me assure him that we regard that charter obligation seriously. We do think the ABC should try to ensure that not only does it cater for the tastes of people all around Australia but that, as much as possible, programs derive from different parts of Australia. I doubt very much that they will be wanting to interview Senator Carr because his quality of bile is well known but I imagine that there will be quite a number of people who will be prepared to go before the committee and we will certainly be very interested in looking at the outcome.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, instead of trying to intimidate and bully the ABC, should not you and Mr Kennett actually be addressing the fact that it is the federal government and its policies that have led to the crippling effects on the ABC's capacity to deliver broadly based programming in Victoria?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI am grateful for the free kick. The fact is that the ABC took a 10 per cent cut in revenue, as many businesses do. It got well in excess of 12 months notice. There has not been any discernible reduction in the range and quality of programs, to my knowledge. The fact is that the decision to relocate services from Melbourne does not appear to have been taken in response to budget cuts. Indeed, as I understand it, the budget for the particular program in question is quite a generous one. I can assure you that we will be making it plain to all and sundry that we expect the ABC to take proper account of its charter obligations and to make sure that it does meet the standards that the parliament expects of it and that it should not be intimidated by the likes of you.

âMy question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Will the minister outline this government's achievements in its first term to improve accountability and transparency in government, including electoral accountability. Are these standards adopted or even shared by other political parties?

âThat is an important question. The coalition is proud of its record in this regard. Never again will the Labor Party be able to deceive the Australian people by saying that the budget would be in surplus instead of what we foundâa $10.3 billion hole. We have put in place a number of measures to improve accountability. We introduced the charter of budget honesty, which requires up-to-date forward estimates of budgetary outlays and revenues at the beginning of each election campaign. We introduced the mid-year economic fiscal outlook to keep people regularly informed. We established the National Commission of Audit to assess the nation's finances. Electorally, we have acted on the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters to improve the integrity of the electoral roll so that Australia's electoral system is immune from abuse and improper behaviour.

answer.para: Our attitude to these matters is contrasted starkly to that of the Labor Party. What are we now hearing about the Labor Party in terms of its internal affairs? Illegal activity, we understand. Former Senator Richardson tells us in this week's Bulletin of alleged illegal activity in relation to branch stacking. He even tells how it is done in the Labor Party. He says:

Usually a willing soldier will be found who is prepared to allow their residence to be used to enrol four or five preselection voters who don't live there. That is a clear breach of the Electoral Act. It involves swearing false delcarations and is a criminal offence.

Can we see Senator Ray racing this stuff off to the police? If there is a rumour about the Liberal Party he is up to the Federal Police in a flash, but it is very different when it is the Labor Party.

There is more information on what has been happening in the Labor Party. We saw it in Victoria on the Channel 9 program and we are now seeing what is happening in Queensland. Former Senator Richardson reminds us of those in the Labor Party from Wollongong who have been charged with that type of rort. He tells us also about what is happening in Townsville, in Queensland, where charges have now been laidâ
Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! There are far too many interjections.

interjection.para: Senator Conroy interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Conroy!

âFormer Senator Richardson tells us about those in the Labor Party who are being charged for this type of matter: Queensland members of the Australian Labor Party. But there is so much more evidence of what is happening within the Labor Party at the moment.
âYou are out of order.
âNo, the contrast, Senator Cook, is which party is fair to govern. Which party has got its house in order.

answer.para: What about the former ALP Victorian state treasurer, Mr Sheehan? He said that a Victorian seat could be bought in the Labor Party for as little as $5,000. That is what happens. A federal seat, he said, for a little bit more.
Honourable senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! The behaviour in the chamber is totally out of order. I would ask senators to exercise some self-discipline and to observe the standing orders.

talk.start.para: âYesterday, Senator Murphy asked me a question without notice about the retirement assistance for farmers scheme which forms part of the Agriculture Advancing Australia package. I said I would refer the senator's question to the responsible minister who happens to be Senator Newman. Senator Newman has provided me with the following information, which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard .

answer.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as followsâ

Yesterday, Senator Murphy asked me a question without notice about the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme (RAFS), which forms part of the `AgricultureâAdvancing Australia' package. I said that I would refer the Senator's question to the Minister for Social Security and Senator Newman has provided me with the following information.

RAFS will allow low income farmers, living in hardship because their farm is being asked to support more than one generation, to pass the farm business onto the younger generation and get immediate access to the age pension. It is unfortunate that the article referred to by Senator Murphy focused on perceived difficulties with RAFS rather than promoting its benefits.

Taxation issues are but one factor to be taken into consideration by older farmers in deciding whether to transfer the farm. In terms of the overall effectiveness of RAFS they need be taken in context:
. many of the RAFS target group will have owned their farms prior to the introduction of Capital Gains Tax and, therefore, will not incur any liability on transfer of the farm;
. the tax liability on the transfer of livestock can be deferred if the farm is operated through a partnership (some 80% of farms involve partnerships);
. as less than 2% of farms are run in company structures, and most of those are outside the RAFS target group, very few would incur a tax liability on transfer of the farm from a company.

Although the tax implications are less widespread than the article would suggest, Centrelink is advising farmers and the younger generation to fully investigate all the implications of a farm transfer, including taxation issues, before acting.

Farmers who do not want to access, or do not qualify for, RAFS may still be able to access the age pension through existing social security provi sions such as the asset hardship provisions, Pensions Loan Scheme, foregone wages, and granny flat provisions.

talk.start.para: âYesterday there was some discussion and points of order relating to my interpretation of standing order 74(5). I confirmed the ruling that I gave at the beginning of the debate but, at the request of Senator Abetz, I said that I would prepare a statement relating to that matter. I incorporate in Hansard the statement that I would make confirming that ruling.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The statement read as followsâ

Yesterday after Question Time several points of order were raised about the procedure under standing order 74(5) whereby a senator may ask for an explanation of the failure to answer a question placed on notice and unanswered for more than 30 days.

Under paragraph (b) of this provision, if a minister provides an explanation of the failure to answer a question, the senator may move a motion that the Senate take note of the explanation. Paragraph (c) provides that, if the minister does not provide an explanation, the senator may move a motion with regard to the minister's failure to provide either an answer or an explanation.

It is clear from the wording of paragraph (c), and many precedents, that, in the absence of an explanation, the senator may move any relevant motion. Usually this motion takes the form of an order for production of the answers, but on one occasion a motion of censure was moved.

It is also clear from the precedents that a statement by a minister that an answer is being prepared, or that the matter is under consideration, is not regarded as an explanation for the purposes of the standing order.

When I referred to a particular precedent of such a statement by a minister not being regarded as an explanation, Senator Abetz asked me to consider whether this one instance should constitute a precedent for the interpretation of the standing order.

There have been four previous occasions on which motions of censure or to order the production of the answers have been moved after a minister made a statement of the kind to which I referred: 25 May 1989, 21 February 1991, 14 March 1991, 11 May 1995.
I am advised that on at least the first two of those occasions the Chair was advised that the motion was in order and the Chair accepted that advice by allowing the motion to be moved.
Also the Senate, by passing the motions, accepted that they were in order.
I therefore confirm the rulings that I made.
