As I think Senator O'Brien mentioned, the Pork Council of Australia has lodged a submission with the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Committee, RASAC, for exceptional circumstances assistance to help it through current adverse circumstances. The minister has asked RASAC to consider the Pork Council's application and it will do so very shortly.

One of the areas in which the government has contributed to the Pork Council is, as Senator Boswell mentioned, a $10 million allocation to the national pig industry development program. The program has put a number of proposals to the government and to the council. It is an important project and it has a number of good ideas. It will certainly help in the short term, and in the longer term, exports are everything.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 March, on motion by Senator Hogg:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: âI want to deal with some matters contained in the annual report of the Department of Industrial Relations, specifically sub-program 1.2âLegal and standards, on page 25 of the report. On page 25 there is a section headed `Objectives'. The department's objectives are:

speech.para: To promote the development and maintenance of an effective legislative and institutional framework.
To ensure that departmental strategies and operations are founded on a sound legal basis and meet applicable legal requirements.
To promote the development of national policy and standards for workers' compensation and OHS.
To support Australia's interests in relation to industrial relations and other labour administration matters at the international level.
It then goes on and describes legal services groups. The legal matters that the department deals with are set out in some detail in the area of the report that I am talking about.

I want to make this point: oftentimes in this chamber when the Senate asks for a legal document, or indeed documents generally, they are refused on the basis that these matters may be sub judice. I want to address that. The idea of sub judice should not be one that covers, as a blanket statement, all documents that are asked for. There should be some examination, not merely of the category of documents but of all documents within a category, to see whether or not they justify the label of a matter which would break the sub judice rule. This report of the Department of Industrial Relations gives some basis for that because it gives quite a defined categorisation of the sorts of things that legal activities should be directed to.

The matters that are listed hardly seem to be ones that would justify the taking of the defence of sub judice. One of the categories relates to Australia's interests in relation to industry relations and other labour administrative matters at the international level. That is the sort of thing that not only this parliament but also the public in general ought to know about. I am taking these matters at random. Another objective is to ensure that departmental strategies and operations are founded on a sound legal basis and meet applicable legal requirements. If there was a legal opinion that had something to say about that test, again, that is something that this parliament ought to know about and that the public generally should know about.

What I am apprehensive about is that there is a risk that objections by the department to producing documents based on the sub judice rule, or indeed any ruleâand it is the department, of course, that passes up the information to the ministerâare being taken too readily and without being properly tested. A reading of the Industrial Relations report in the area that I have spoken about illustrates what I am talking about.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 March, on motion by Senator Bartlett.
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: âAs a former delegate on a Political Exchange Council delegation, I would like to speak in support of the role that the council plays and the work that is put into it. It is a body that does not cost very much in the way of funding. It gets about $400,000 in terms of federal government funding, plus the assistance and support of a number of organisations by way of sponsorship and `in kind' donations.

speech.para: Since its inauguration in the early 1980s up until the time of this report, it has enabled 329 different Australians to participate in a range of delegations to a wide number of countries. They have had a first-hand opportunity to see in detail the operation of the political systems, the economic systems and other aspects of those countries. They have been able to absorb that knowledge and bring it back to Australia to assist them in being able to make a more valuable contribution to Australian society.

From my own experience, it is an extremely valuable program. In September 1995, a couple of years before I came into this place, I was a delegate on a trip to Germany. This gave me an enormous insight into many aspects of Germany and a greater appreciation of the importance of the role that it plays in Europe. I was able to appreciate the links that it has with Australia and the many opportunities that are presented to Australia in the German and broader European context. I am sure that sure the same sorts of insight and opportunities are provided to delegates who have gone to other countries.

In speaking to the report, I would like to strongly support the work of the Political Exchange Council. The council is chaired by Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. It also involves a number of other people, including the secretary of the Australian Democrats, Sam Hudson, who has put a great amount of work into her role. Over eight years she has taken her responsibilities very seriously. She has ensured that the Democrat members of delegations are suitable so that they will be able to contribute to the broader society and community and to politics in general in Australia on their return. The fact that she enabled me to go on one of those delegations might indicate a lapse of judgment, but other than that she has had a pretty good record.

A number of my Democrat colleagues past and present have also been delegates on various visits overseas, including the current Leader of the Democrats, Senator Lees, and the Deputy Leader of the Democrats, Senator Stott Despoja. The parliamentary leader of the Democrats in South Australia, Mr Mike Elliott, is another one, as is the deputy leader over there for the Democrats, Sandra Kanck. The program has certainly provided a lot of worthwhile opportunity to Democrat members, not just to people who go into parliament but to people who contribute to society in many other areas and at many other levels.

The year that this report relates to had six delegations and Democrat representatives were on three of those. Kerri Kellett, who was on the delegation to the UK, Pierre Harcourt, who was on the delegation to the USA, and Alex Bowie, who was on another delegation to Vietnam, had the pleasure of being on the delegation chaired and led by Senator Abetz, which I am sure was a great pleasure for him. In fact I know it was, because he speaks often and highly of Senator Abetz, who was obviously such a great participant in the program and such a noble ambassador for the Liberals that they have enabled him to go on two of these delegations, to Germany in 1991 and then on this other delegation, to Vietnam in 1996. No doubt that is an indication of his importance and the worthwhile contribution that he makes to the Liberals, unless they were hoping he might get lost over there the second time around.

In closing I would like to reinforce my support for the existence of the council and encourage the government to continue to provide its support. I also encourage reciprocal governments in other countries to recognise the valuable role that the council plays. Certainly in terms of my experience in Germany it has been of ongoing value to me. I encourage all governments who have contributed to this program to continue to support it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to inform the Senate of the progress in Newcastle on the announcement by BHP that it was phasing out the smelting of steel. I would like to clarify something about which there is widespread misunderstanding in the community. In Newcastle BHP is not closing. Steel smelting is closing in Newcastle. Rod and bar and wire products will still be produced in Newcastle from billets that are brought up from South Australia.

speech.para: One and a half million tonnes of processed steel will still go out the main gate of BHP every year, just as it has done in the past. All the downstream industries will still gain the benefits of having steel produced in Newcastle. There is a widespread misunderstanding that it is all finishing. Let me assure everyone listening tonight that it is not.

Twelve months ago, the Prime Minister went to Newcastle to speak with community, business and union groups about the closure and the effects on Newcastle. Quite a number of ministers also went there at that time. Last week I went to BHP to receive an update on the plans for the downsizing of BHP. I met with Brad McMahon, who is the BHP human resources manager, and Lance Hockeridge, who is the general manager. When we were all there about a year ago, what was proposed, with the 2,500 workers who were going to lose their positions, was at that stage just theory. What I was able to see in my visit there one year on was how those plans are being brought to fruition. I would like to particularly commend BHP on the way in which they have gone about the whole exercise. It is really a textbook approach to how, when a major industry in a region finishes up, the provider of those industrial services treats its workers.

Currently 2,300 people are employed at BHP in Newcastle. Their average age is 42 years and their average length of service is just under 20 years. So, on average, there is a very large group of people whose only work involvement has been at the BHP site in Newcastle, and who now have to move on to a new phase in their life because a great number of them are still in their 30s and 40s. What BHP has put in place is a very impressive transition arrangement and I had the opportunity last week to speak to the transition team. This is a team of people representing all different sections of the steelworks. I had half an hour listening to where they were up to in their training adjustment, and they had the opportunity to question me for about half an hour on how the government was responding to what was happening at BHP.

The principles of the transition team are very impressive. They feel people must be treated fairly and feel very well prepared for the future. Their second principle is that the businessâBHP steelworksâmust run safely and efficiently through the transition period. The thing about a steelworks, particularly an integrated steelworks, is that you just cannot phase it down gradually. You cannot produce 1Â½ million tonnes and then a million tonnes and then half a million tonnes; you have to run it full belt for it work efficiently, and that is exactly what they plan to do. They will be running at full belt right up to the end of next year, and then it all shuts down at one point in time. They have actually provided special bonuses to the workers to stay on for that full time to the end. The interesting thing about the figures produced by BHP at the moment is that their efficiency rates in production are still going up and the work accident rate is still dropping. They have a highly motivated team there that is determined to work the plant in a proper way right to the end.

But by the end of next year, 2,300 people will have to go. They are all receiving help with financial and career planning, personal counselling and retirement planning. They are being provided with the opportunity for small business courses and also training and education assistance. This unique package was developed in a partnership between the employees, the unions and BHP. Their initiatives are quite impressive, particularly in the areas of education and training. I was impressed to see the number that were actually going on to further education and higher education at this point. One hundred and seventy are planning to go to university and 240-odd are going on to do other TAFE training. So there is quite a lot of reskilling going on in this process.

BHP, in their personal counselling and case management of the workers, have developed personal action plans with these people. They are given help to explore and investigate career options, to determine their career goals and to develop job search strategies. Of the 2,300 employees, 1,500 of them have had at least one personal action plan discussion with this group and with counsellors. The time that is spent on this by BHP is quite impressive. Over 700 employees have determined their future directionâthey know what they are going to doâand over 400 have commenced retraining. BHP is ensuring that workers in the Hunter region are not left in the lurch when the steel smelting actually shuts down at the end of next year.

The other thing that BHP is doing in the region that is very impressive is helping to create industry beyond the time when steel smelting ceases. There were reports this week that BHP and Baulderstone Hornibrook are working together to develop Newcastle's Steel River Industrial Park. BHP has already spent several million on this development, and is planning to spend a lot more. This will be Australia's first eco-industrial site. It is designed for value-added, export-focused manufacturing business. What was very timely and one of the triggers for this policy was the Howard government's creation of the manufacturing in bonds scheme. This enables people to set up export oriented industries in places like Newcastle and have relief on things such as customs duty, so it is more attractive to set up an export oriented industry in Australia.

The local and state governments have cooperated in this process by guaranteeing a 28-day approval process for industries setting up, and that will be a great attraction for industries coming from overseas. It is expected that this will create up to 2,000 jobs in the Newcastle area. So BHP, being a responsible corporate citizen in the Newcastle region, is trying to leave behind as many jobs as are actually going with the end of steel smelting.

The Howard government has come in and assisted this process a great deal. We have establishedâthe Prime Minister announced it last yearâa $10 million fund for infrastructure, and already $5 million is committed to two major infrastructure projects: $3 million for electricity infrastructure on Kooragang Island and also an in-principle agreement of $2 million for local shipbuilding. The rest will go to projects which will generate best long-term outcomes for the Hunter. In addition to this fund, the Howard government has spent millions on the Hunter. We have given, with the infrastructure bonds scheme, a $30 million break to the establishment of the $600 million Redbank power station, which will employ in its construction phase up to 1,000 people.

The emphasis on these sorts of projects and on a range of other projects, such as business incubators and environmental schemes, is showing that the Howard government is actually coming in and supporting the Hunter, and it has had a great effect on morale in the area. The morale that was low when the announcement was made by BHP in April last year has picked up, not only because of this assistance but also because of the great win of the Knights at the end of last year, which was a huge morale booster to the area, and they will repeat that this year.

talk.start.para: âNext week is Medical Research Week, and tonight I would like to bring to the attention of the Senate the need for research into the diagnosis and treatment of spider bite, and in particular that of the white-tailed spider. I tabled in parliament today a petition from almost 3,000 Australians who are concerned about the lack of research funding for the development of a diagnostic test and treatment for white-tailed spider bites. These particular spiders may not be as well-known as some other venomous Australian spiders such as the red-back or the funnel-web but their bites can cause very severe reactions and in some cases result in death. There is no antivenom available for the white-tailed spider. Indeed, some have suggested it might actually be safer for you to be bitten by a red-back or a funnel-web, as long that you get immediate attention, than it is to be bitten by these spiders.

speech.para: White-tailed spiders are extremely widespread. They are in all states right across the country. They can be found in most Australian homes and gardens. Unlike most species of spider, both the male and female are venomous. Bites from the spiders cause painful blisters that do not heal. Many people report bites that get worse and worse with time as the tissue dies and the site becomes ulcerated. In some cases this has led to gangrene and amputation. The wounds can be extremely painful, and the long-term symptoms have led to depression and reduced quality of life for sufferers.

Helen Midgley from South Australia has written to me describing her experiences, and she is happy for me to detail them here tonight. Her experiences after being a bitten on the foot by a spider when gardening make it clear why there is an urgent need to put research funds into finding a successful remedy. Mrs Midgley sought treatment for her spider bite but the initial treatment was unsuccessful. She was prescribed several courses of antibiotics and these had no impact at all. The site became ulcerated, with the skin around the area slowly dying, and this ulcerated area gradually expanded. She then had hyperbaric treatment in an oxygen chamber. This was also unsuccessful, and after ten weeks the ulcerated wound was obviously continuing to grow.

She saw a plastic surgeon and had an operation to cut out the entire ulcerated area and then went through the process of having a skin graft. By this time Mrs Midgley was in severe pain 24 hours a day, could not sleep and could not perform simple domestic tasks. The skin graft was unsuccessful too. It be came infected and began to die. A second skin graft was performed which removed more skin around the site. This second graft was successful in preventing further tissue death, but she required an eight-week stay in hospital and was wheelchair bound for quite some time after she returned home. Sixteen months after being bitten, Mrs Midgley is still experiencing pain in her foot, as the nerves damaged by the spider bite were very slow to repair themselves. She says that her wound is still numb and the skin graft itself is still causing some discomfort.

This is just one story. There are, unfortunately, many stories from all around Australia that are only too similar to this. In terms of both money and human suffering, these spiders can cause major difficulties. It demonstrates that there is an urgent need for a convenient diagnostic test, one that all doctors can be made aware of, and an effective antivenom to be developed. The Australian Venom Research Unit is investigating the problem of necrotising spider bites such as those of the white-tailed spider. Unfortunately, this promising research is at a near standstill due to a lack of funding. This should be of concern to all of us because, as I said, we come into contact with these spiders daily, certainly weekly, and for us and our children we do not know whether we are going to be the lucky one who has nothing more than a slight bump which we barely notice or whether we are going to be one of those unlucky ones such as Mrs Midgley.

There is considerable evidence in the community that people are concerned. If we look at the 1996 Victorian Poisons Information Centre report, they have reported that problems regarding unidentified spider bites were the second most common requests for advice. They were the second most common problem that people had who rang up for information. The withdrawal of Commonwealth funding for this important research occurred shortly after the government decided to privatise the Commonwealth Serum Laboratoriesâsomething the Democrats strongly opposed. A recent submission by the Australian Venom Research Unit states that the decision to privatise CSL has resulted in, firstly, significantly reduced venom and antivenom funding; secondly, reduced support for Australian venom research and researchers; thirdly, the cessation or disruption of important research projects; fourthly, decreased opportunities for training and education of health and medical professionals in the area of venom research and treatment; and, fifthly, the loss to Australia of many opportunities to achieve international commercial medical research leadership.

I am disappointed that the sale of CSL occurred without any look at the long-term consequences in this particular area. Australia had an excellent record of first-rate antivenom research, but unfortunately our global leadership in this area has been severely negatively affected by the privatisation of CSL and the associated withdrawal of Commonwealth funding.

The impact of privatisation on research and development in the area of venom and antivenom research appears to have been ignored entirely during that privatisation process. This particular area of research is obviously not an isolated case. If we look right across the whole spectrum of medical research we find there is a cumulative effect of the lack of government support.

The survey recently conducted by the Australian Society for Medical Research looked at Australian trained medical researchers currently working outside this country. The study found that 73 per cent of these researchers had completed their highest degree in Australia before leaving. This means that Australia does not benefit from all that we are investing in educating people or in training these medical researchers.

The main reason they left was to gain employment opportunities not available in Australia. Seventy-three per cent of those surveyed stated that their salary was better than what they would have received for an equivalent job here. While almost three-quarters of the researchers stated a desire to return if they could find suitable employment, it seems that opportunities in this country are severely lacking. Sixty-six per cent said they would have to remain overseas for some time as they were highly unlikely to find equiva lent jobs and the career prospects were minimal in Australia. This is a sad indictment on the lack of support of this and previous governments for medical research when our best and brightest are forced offshore because they cannot get work here.

The government recently said again that it is committed to medical researchâand I am getting this out of the budget papers. We hope this commitment actually translates into something concrete by way of direct and specific funding. As a priority I ask that the government considers the urgent need for a treatment for white-tailed spider bite. We need to develop it as a matter of urgency and the funding needs to be allocated for this important research. After all, they are uniquely Australian. They occur nowhere else in the world. We cannot sit back and wait for somebody else to do our work for us. This is an Australian spider and we need an Australia solution.

talk.start.para: âI rise this evening to follow up on issues that were raised during question time today by Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Family Services. Child care remains a critical issue confronting Australian families. Whilst this government has been in power, no less than $820 million has been cut out of the child-care budget. The implications of these budget cuts are significant. Whilst the government uses these cuts to parade around their tightening fiscal attitudes and to subsequently promote what they claim as a glorious budget surplus, thousands upon thousands of Australian families are now having to change their arrangements and alter their family budgets just to get by.

speech.para: I would like to highlight two main flaws in the response by the minister in this afternoon's question time. The first is the issue in relation to new places for child care. We have heard the minister and other ministers before him in this place talk about the 7,000 places created for long day care in terms of government support. But the point is that, whilst the government can stand up and show an increase in the dollar line on their budget papers in terms of places, we have a remarkable reduction in the actual expenditure on what the anticipated trend growth rate was for those places. What we had was a government that said, `We will maintain child-care funding for places,' but what the government did was to actively cut that in half. In addressing the trend growth for demand in full day care places for children in this country, we have a government that has not addressed the demand; they have, in fact, halved what the requirement is. In real terms, politically and in the practical effect on families, this is a halving of services. It is a halving of the opportunities for Australian families.

The second point I would like to raise specifically is the distinction between services. The question put to the minister today related specifically to out of school hours care. The response that came back was dismal in the sense that the minister could not differentiate between the long day care services to which he related his reply and the out of school hours care services to which the question explicitly related. The issue is that the cuts and structural changes to the way this government provides support to families with children in care, be it to the parents or to the services themselves, are doing three major things.

Firstly, the viability of those services is being reduced. This is being done through the withdrawal of operational subsidies for both the community long day care and out of school hours care. The withdrawal of this operational subsidy in turn attacks, in many cases, the viability of the centres. Many of these centres operate as a small business does, with cash flow being a critical element in their business plan. The way operational subsidies were applied, they greatly assisted these centres with regard to support and viability in that critical financial sense. The payment of child-care assistance in arrears also affects the viability of these centres in that structural way, once again affecting cash flow and threatening the viability.

Anyone who has had any experience with a child-care centre will know that staffing arrangements and the relationship to the number of children in care really determines a week by week margin for that particular centre. Any alteration to those arrangements can mean the difference between that centre getting above the line or falling below it and operating in the red.

The other issue with regard to the reduction of the viability of the services goes straight to out of school hours care. The same implications in terms of the viability of running these services are affected by the cutting of the operational subsidy and other structural changes. I know in my home town here in Canberra that many of those out of school hours care services provided at each primary school are now being forced to combine with other schools, placing a requirement of travel on those children between the schools. In relation to one of the services I am most familiar with, they will no longer to be able to provide a vacation care service because of the financial pressures on that service.

I think the issue this raises is that of the dry approach by this government in looking at the dollar bottom line and what it is trying to achieve in the support for families and parents in the forms of care. What we need is a system that provides the best service for the children. We need a system that services the needs of the child and the parents. If this means that the child goes to out of school hours care in their own school, it means they do not have to travel between schools, and that is a safety issue as well.

If you want to take out the factor about the child's safety, their wellbeing and stability, then you can start looking at the bottom line and you can start forcing efficiencies like primary schools combining their out of schools hours care service and vacation care being removed from each school that provides that service and also being combined. When you take out children as a factor in your policy considerations, you can also proceed with your agenda. One of the specific things that I referred to is the operational subsidy.

When you do not factor in the welfare of the child or the needs of the parent, then you can start removing operational subsidies to force fees up. We have seen a rise of approximately $25 to $30 per child where the operational subsidy has been removed from community long day care. The resulting cost increases have been significant enough to change the lifelong careers and prospects for many parents. I know women who have left work or have changed their arrangements in terms of longer or shorter leave or have gone from full-time to part-time work or part-time to full-time work in an intervening period anticipating that they are not going to be able to sustain that period of work for very long because of the increased costs. I know women who are delaying having children because they are too concerned about the financial imposition or the non-accessibility of places that they can afford. These resulting cost increases have also caused many womenâand in many cases some men as wellâto decide to no longer be a family where two parents work.

It is hard to address these issues in isolation. I would like to put these issues in the context of other policies of this government. Industrial relations comes to mind with the continued downward pressure on wages and conditions of working Australians. When you combine that political agenda on families and you look at the context of the prospect of not a significant wage increase in the short-term because of changes to industrial relationsâand I know it is more complex than thatâwhen you double that with an imposition such as that which we are seeing in child care instead of seeing families progressing in society under policies that Labor put in place that allowed for scope and wider participation in the work force you start to see a government that is prepared to put the shackles on working women in particular and put the shackles on the opportunities and choices that families have.

The other area that I think is worth a specific mention is the disincentives that this government has put in place for working families with more than one child in care. There have been a number of initiatives which basically put people with more than one child in care out of the picture. No longer can they afford to take on that role because of the financial imposition. So we have a social agenda on behalf of this government that forces one parent out of work if they have more than one child in care.

There were two specific budget changes which created a greater financial imposition on parents with more than one child in care. It is hypocritical of a government which says that it is committed to small business and to families and even says that it cares about children. The viability of centres, the disincentive for parents to work if they have more than one child in care and the rising costs expose this government that they are not committed to children's welfare. They are prepared to put the dollar before their welfare and the ability of those parents to make active and viable choices about how they care for their children if they choose to work. (Time expired)

âTonight I wish to appraise the background of the coalition's success in its economic management of the economy. As we all know, economIndustry Commission growth is not a smooth or an even process. In fact, growth fluctuates around its long-term trend, and to the eternal fascination of economists also the timing of business cycles is not regular. Indeed, timing is random. Part of the Treasury responsibility is to focus on trying to understand these business cycles, their timing, their causes and their effects so that government can provide policies which can control business cycle activity.

speech.para: Changes in policy instruments do affect the economy, some more dramatically than others. Therefore, it is not surprising that economists do not always agree on the extent to which policy instruments impact on the economy. The job of managing the economy, therefore, is often a controversial one. Governments around the world, including our Australian government, are constantly looking for policy combinations that would deliver strong and sustainable economic growth, low unemployment, low inflation, balanced budgets, balanced international accounts and low volatility of real GDP fluctuations around trend growth.

In this regard Australia through its government has been particularly successful. Fiscal policy, monetary policy, wages and incomes policy and industry policies are all tools used by the coalition to achieve these goals. However, simultaneously achieving them all at the same time is often a difficult task. The Australian economy, after a slow start in 1996, picked up significantly in terms of growth in 1997. The pick up was mainly led by stronger domestic demand, with a cyclical upswing in the housing sector and a firmer trend in consumer demand. The labour market improved, with employment and labour force participation rising and unemployment beginning to decline. Not since December 1990 has the unemployment rate, seasonally adjusted, been lower. Driven by high levels of housing affordability the dwelling sector continues to contribute to growth. Export quantities displayed good growth through 1997, and strong growth in imports over the same period confirms the strength of domestic demand.

The strengthening in domestic activity brought about a strong increase in employment in the last half of 1997, and most of this increase was in full-time employment. With the rise in the demand for labour, unemployment fortunately has begun to fall. Encouraged by improved employment prospects, retail trade strengthened mid-year and motor vehicle sales have been particularly strong. In fact, retail trade rose a seasonally adjusted 0.7 per cent in March, indicating a continuing healthy domestic demand.

As has frequently be said in this chamber, interest rates are at a historic low, and housing loan rates are at their lowest for 30 years. Declines in interest rates have benefited the nearly 30 per cent of households with home loans and driven housing affordability to its current extremely high level. This, in turn, has underpinned the gradual expansion in dwelling investment. The Treasurer, Mr Costello, constantly refers to this strong consumer demand. Total building approvals jumped a seasonally adjusted 9.8 per cent in March, with a 4.2 per cent for private sector houses.

Consistent with the pick-up in consumer spending and the gradual trend towards lower interest rates is the improvement in business trading conditions since the first half of 1997. In fact, the Yellow Pages survey of small business, the National Australia Bank survey of firms across the whole non-farm economy, the ACCI-Westpac survey of manufacturing, and the Dun and Bradstreet survey of manufacturing, retailing and wholesaling have all reported upward trends in business sentiment.

Due to the Asian economic crisis, however, positive sentiment was reduced in the March quarter, showing a negative net result for the first time since December 1995. While the economic meltdown in Asia has tended to cloud investment expectations, we really do need to analyse our trade and the extent of trade and prices country by country. Our most important markets of Japan and Korea have taken strong measures to assist the recovery processâJapan by lowering taxes, by government spending in infrastructure and other areas; Korea, of course, by its own efforts to overcome its difficulties, assisted greatly by the international community.

To date, the government's strong management of the economy and its policy of trade diversification have resulted in Australia's exports holding up remarkably wellâand, I might say, against the odds. Exports were up $8 billion in the first eight months of this financial yearâa 12.1 per cent increase. Diversification of product and markets have prevented the external shock from taking an undue immediate toll on Australia's trade performance.

What I would say is that the big risk for Australia is undoubtedly the possibility of a meltdown in China. I have had very interesting discussions on this matter with my colleague Senator O'Chee, who is of Chinese descent. The impact of a decline in property prices in Hong Kong and downward movements in the share market in Hong Kong could move across to depress Mainland China values and I think we could well expect some depreciation of the China currencyâthe Yuanâwhich could subsequently have quite a significant impact on Australia-China trade. So I say to listeners that the place to watch is perhaps not so much Indonesiaâalthough that country's problems are essentially economic but leading to social dislocation and inflation of food prices. Australia's focus in the immediate future should certainly be on China.

Market diversification has been under way for the past two years, a period over which exports have continued to increase in value, notwithstanding Japan's stagnant economy. Undoubtedly at least part of the diversification in the increase of products in export markets has been driven by contrary movements in the value of the dollarâup against East Asian currencies but down against the US dollar and the major European currencies. It is not surprising in such an environment that the numbers of tourists to Australia are decreasing from places such as Korea but are tending to increase from Europe because of differences in relative exchange rates.

Australia, given its integration with Asian markets, is clearly more exposed than many other countries to developments in the region, with the possible exception of New Zealand. The decline in Asian demand has led policy makers elsewhere to take a more relaxed view of their own growth in order to absorb the global demand slack and China's stern intent to maintain the value of the yuan. I think this may be seriously tested following the results of the last day or two, and Asian currencies do fluctuate widely on a daily basis.

Most of the expected growth in investment in 1997-98 is certainly in the mining industry. I was privileged to attend a mining industry dinner last night and to hear of some of the remarkable contributions that its members make to the Australian economy. The decline in global commodity prices over recent months is a cause of some concern and may contribute to a waning confidence in this sector. However, the appreciation of the Australian dollar against major currencies is expected to support long-term profitability.

The Reserve Bank has an inflation targetâan independent targetâof between two and three per cent. Inflation expectations remain close to their lowest levels for a generation. Keeping both wage and price aspirations to a realistic level will play a big part in achieving the banks' and the government's targets. Inflation is currently well under control. This is a remarkable achievement given the history of double digit inflation since the 1970s.

The government is committed to low inflation because it assists business to make sound investment decisions and underpins the creation of new and lasting jobs. Low and steady inflation gives savers and investors confidence to make long-term decisions and provides clear signals on the best allocation of resources. Low inflation provides the underpinning for the strong, sustained growth required to make lasting inroads into unemp

loyment. The low inflation Australia has experienced is not accidental. It is a direct result of the government's policies, which have enabled us to weather the financial instability in a much better shape than other economies in our region.

Annual wage growth remains under the Reserve Bank's 4.5 per cent comfort level. Manufacturing settlements are still considered to be high but ultimately what is an acceptable wage gain is governed by productivity growth.

If there is one lesson that we should take from Asia, it is that adverse, external events can arise quickly and with significant effects. Sensible economic management means strengthening the position not only to meet known challenges but also to provide for contingencies. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 12 March 1998:

subdebateinfo.title: East Gippsland, Tasmania and Central Highlands Regional Forest Agreements
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1123)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 2 April 1998:

question.para: With reference to the East Gippsland, Tasmania and Central Highlands Regional Forest Agreements (RFAs):

(1) Which power or precedent enables the Commonwealth to bind future Governments to the payment of compensation if the intentions of logging and mining companies are thwarted by Commonwealth action to protect the environment, as the Tasmanian and Central Highlands RFAs purport to do.
(2) How much money has been spent on the preparation of each of the three RFAs signed so far.

(3) (a) How much money has been allocated to the implementation of each of the RFAs; (b) of this, how much is from the Natural Heritage Trust, how much is from other existing programs, specifying which programs, and how much is new money; and (c) in total, how much is from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and how much is from the Department of the Environment.
(4) Why is legislation being prepared to give effect to the RFAs if they are already legally binding.

(5) Of the native forest woodchips exported since each of the RFAs was signed: (a) what volumes exported by which companies were covered under export licences, specifying the licence numbers; and (b) what volumes exported by which companies were not covered by export licences.

(6) If the State Government authorised native forest logging, in an area covered by a RFA, which failed to comply with its own legislation, management plans or codes of conduct: (a) would it contravene the RFA; and (b) what action could the Commonwealth take.

talk.start.para: âThe Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Under both the Tasmanian and Central Highlands RFAs, the Commonwealth will pay compensation to the State if it takes any action during the period of the RFA which is inconsistent with any provision of the RFA and a probable or foreseeable consequence of which is to prevent or substantially limit:
(i) the use of land which is not included in the comprehensive, adequate and representative (CAR) reserve system for forestry operations; or
(ii) the sale or commercial use of forest products sourced from land which is not included within the CAR reserve system; or

(iii) the construction on land which is not included within the CAR reserve system of roads being built or intended to be built where the primary purpose of those roads is for the transportation of forest products sourced from land which is not included in the CAR reserve system.

While this provision is contained in a part of the RFA which is expressed to be legally binding, clause 92 provides that if such provisions cannot create legally enforceable rights or obligations, the provisions are to be read as not intending to create legally enforceable rights and obligations.
The government is well aware that no government, current or future, can bind the Parliament to appropriate moneys whether for the payment of compensation or otherwise.
(2) Provisional estimates of expenditure by the Commonwealth on the preparation of the three RFAs are as follows: Tasmaniaâ$7.7 million; East Gippsland and Central Highlandsâ$12.2 million.

It should be noted that these figures are estimates and are based on a number of assumptions regarding allocation of costs across portfolios. It should also be noted that it is not possible to provide an accurate disaggregation of costs associated with the East Gippsland and Central Highlands RFAs because many expenses were incurred on a State rather than regional basis.
(3) (a) East GippslandâNo allocation; Central Highlandsâ$13.8 million; Tasmaniaâ$110 million.

(b) East GippslandâNot applicable; Central Highlandsâ$13.8 million from the Forest Industry Structural Adjustment Package (FISAP); Tasmaniaâ$20 million from the Natural Heritage Trust, $90 million in new appropriations.

(c) East GippslandâNot applicable; Central HighlandsâDPIE $13.8 million; TasmaniaâOf the $90 million in new appropriations, $71 million is to be provided through DPIE, $16 million through DoE and $3 million through DIST.

(4) Only part three of the Tasmanian and Central Highlands RFAs is expressed to be legally binding. The primary reason for the legislation is to give effect to some key provisions which are not expressed to be legally binding in the Tasmanian and Central Highlands RFAs, thereby providing greater certainty about the operation of RFAs.

(5) (a) Between the date of signing of the East Gippsland RFA (3 February 1997) and the commencement of the Export Control (Regional Forest Agreement) Regulations (the RFA Regulations), on 14 April 1997, two companies exported native forest woodchips under RFA licences issued for that region under the 1996 Regulations, namely:

(b) Given that the RFAs themselves provide for the conservation of the environment and heritage values of native forests, the RFA Regulations provide that while an RFA is in force for a region, woodchips and unprocessed wood sourced from native forests in that region are not prescribed goods within the meaning of the Export Control (Hardwood Wood Chips) (1996) Regulations (the 1996 Regulations) and the Export Control (Unprocessed Wood) Regulations. Since 14 April 1997, as a consequence of the operation of the RFA regulations, exporters of such material have not required an export licence. No company-specific data on the volume of forest woodchip exports without licences are therefore available.

(6) It is not possible to provide a categorical answer to either parts (a) or (b) of this question without knowing what specific breaches or conduct was envisaged. Action would contravene the RFA if it was not consistent with the RFA.

answer.para: (1) Federal Government assistance is provided in two parts, income support and interest rate subsidies.
As at 1 May 1998, there were 2,743 farmers receiving the Exceptional Circumstances Relief Payment:

Of these recipients, 2,897 had been in receipt of ECRP for more than 3 years, 2,253 for between 2 and 3 years, 1,439 for between 1 and 2 years and the remaining 1,611 for up to 1 year. Some farmers in Queensland who are currently in receipt of DEC IRS assistance may have been accessing this type of assistance since 1993 due to continuing DEC status, provided that they that they have not exceeded the maximum level of allowable support under the RAS.

Upon revocation of DEC status, farmers in those revoked areas would still be eligible to apply for a further 12 months of DEC IRS, within the 6 months recovery period.

ECRP is available to eligible farmers in areas declared as experiencing exceptional circumstances. Upon revocation of EC status, eligible farmers are still entitled to receive ECRP within the 12 months recovery period.

Farmers in NSW and Queensland DEC areas which were revoked on 7 July 1997 (except for those areas within Flinders, Aramac and Winton Shires in Queensland which have been re-instated on 8 April 1998) are no longer eligible to apply for DEC IRS as the 6 months recovery period ended on 6 January 1998. Farmers in Cobar and Wilcannia (south of the Barrier Highway and south of that portion of the Darling River east of Wilcannia) RLPBs in NSW which were revoked on 31 December 1997 have up to 30 June 1998 to apply for DEC IRS. Eligible farmers are still entitled to receive ECRP until 30 December 1998.

(c) As at March 1998, there were 814 farmers in Queensland who were in the recovery period and had received DEC interest rate subsidies. There were an estimated 779 Queensland farmers in receipt of the ECRP who were in their recovery period.

As at March 1998, there are 131 farmers in NSW who were in the recovery period and had received DEC interest rate subsidies. There were an estimated 200 NSW farmers in receipt of the ECRP who were in their recovery period. ECRP for approximately 140 NSW farmers who are located in EC areas revoked on 7 July 1997 will cease on 6 July 1998. ECRP payments will cease for 60 farmers on 30 December 1998.
No farmers are in a recovery period in the other States.

(d) Farmers in NSW and Queensland DEC areas which were revoked on 7 July 1997 (except for those areas within Flinders, Aramac and Winton Shires in Queensland which have been re-instated on 8 April 1998) are no longer eligible to apply for DEC IRS as the 6 months recovery period ended on 6 January 1998. However eligible farmers are still entitled to receive ECRP until 30 December 1998.

(3) Farmers eligible for ECRP may also receive additional family payment for dependent children, exemption from the assets test for Austudy recipients and a health care card.
